Eugene Hollander, the nursing-home operator, was sentenced yesterday to spend five nights a week in jail for up to six months and was ordered to sever all connections with nursing homes for inflating Medicare reimbursement claims by more than $100,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (Reuters) City Lights, the poetry publishing company that brought out "a little red book" of the thoughts of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, reports the book has become its biggest best seller since "Howl," by Allen Ginsberg, the Beat poet.

WASHINGTON, May 4 Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the Ford Administration was undermining American "moral support" for Israel by putting undue pressure on it to make concessions to the Arabs.

Residents of Parker Towers, a complex of three 22story apartment buildings on Queens Boulevard in Queens, felt the first effects of the building service employees' walkout yesterday. They were told, among other things, not to move out or have parties until the strike is over.

WILLARD, Utah, May 4 Melvin Dummar said today that he intended to press for the one-sixteenth share of the $1.5 billion estate of Howard R. Hughes that is allotted to him in a purported will that turned up in Salt Lake City last week.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 4 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger cautioned third-world nations today against using "bloc economic power" to narrow the economic gap between rich and poor countries. At the same time he pledged American cooperation in their development efforts.

KENT, Ohio, May 4 (AP) A memorial boycott of classes was held today at Kent State University on the sixth anniversary of its bloody Vietnam War protest. While some students picketed, others attended class.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 Representative Ray J. Madden the 84-year-old chairman of the House Rules Committee, was defeated tonight by State Senator Adam Benjamin Jr. in the Democratic primary in Indiana's 1st Congressional District.
The Uniroyal Chemical unit of Uniroyal announced yesterday that it was increasing prices on its ABS Kralastic plastic, effective June 1.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, will not campaign in Connecticut and will try to have his name removed from the May 11 ballot, a spokesman said today.
ATLANTA, May 4 Former Gov. Jimmy Carter swept to victory over two principal rivals in the nonbinding Democratic Presidential preference primary here tonight.

DENVER, May 4 The Denver Nuggets survived a New York zone press and a whirlwind named Julius Erving tonight to gain a 127-121 victory over the Nets and even the American Basketball Association championship series at one game apiece.

With mixed feelings, I tender my resignation as a judge of the Family Court, effective May 14, 1976. I plan to return to the practice of law. I also expect to be active in public affairs and politics as I have been in the past.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market finished yesterday with minor price changes in continued slow trading.

Exactly at the midway point in his Mozart concerto series, Daniel Barenboim took himself and the English Chamber Orchestra through three full-scale works last night in Carnegie Hall. One says "full-scale" because none of the juvenile concertos were on the program. There was, however, No. 9 in E flat (K.271), the work that marks the break between Mozart's innocence and full maturity.

The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, yesterday joined the United States Steel Corporation and others, in raising prices for hot-and cold-rolled sheet and galvanized sheet, effective June 14.

BOCA RATON, Fla., May 5 Maybe it's necessary for book publishers to leave town in order to contemplate themselves and their ways. New York is to publishing what water is to sticklebacks: the quotidian. And even the most intelligent and introspective stickleback would have a hard time, while under water, thinking about the aquadynamics of swimming or the concept of wetness. One publishes, one swims, one doesn't ask existential questions.

"They know I'm very tender these days," she said.

WHEN American 19th-century quilts became collectibles a decade ago, few of us realized that a major revival had begun and that 10 years later there would be so much for experts, museums, auctions and shops to unravel.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 6 Golfers find it difficult to post good medal scores at the Seawane Club, a beautiful course sliced here and there by Thixton Creeks, Mallow Reach and a short canal leading to Lake Kathellen, which is only a pond back of the third green.

Blending down-home religion with uptown society, Vice President Rockefeller and scores of leading New Yorkers gathered at the Pierre Hotel last night to pay tribute to Elisabeth Luce Moore for her 38 years of devotion to the United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia.
WASHINGTON Business, labor, Congress and the Administration are moving toward an electionyear battle over legislation dealing with the minimum wage.
Don Bankhead, the first black pitcher in major league baseball, died of cancer at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Houston on Sunday, one day before his 55th birthday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 Several Republican leaders have advised President Ford in recent days that criticism of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's handling of foreign policy issues was hurting Mr. Ford among Republican voters and had played a significant role in the primary victories of Ronald Reagan.
The stock market, adhering to its recent pattern of small daily advances alternating with small declines, edged up yesterday in continued light trading.

It is not because of the building employes' strike that Susana Cardona had to carry her groceries up 76 steps yesterday. She always does. There is no elevator at 239 East 115th Street, where the Cardona family lives.

The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday told Judge David N. Edelstein, the trial judge in the Justice Department's antitrust action against I.B.M., that the Government was using the Federal Bureau of Investigation to interview I.B.M.'s trial witnesses.

GENEVA, May 6 Syria called on the World Health Organization today to impose "appropriate sanctions" on Israel, charging that the Israelis had "grossly disregarded" the rights of the Palestinian people.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The Securities and Exchange Commission withdrew today two of three proposals it put forward last fall that would have substantially expanded the amount of environmental compliance information available to investors.

Despite a threatened defection by Brooklyn Republicans, the overwhelming majority of New York delegates to the Republican National Convention are ready to follow the lead of Vice President Rockefeller and thus enhance his bargaining power at the convention, state Republican leaders agreed yesterday.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 6 Karen Anne Quinlan's physicians have begun a series of diagnostic tests in order to describe her condition accurately for a hospital ethics committee, which must determine that there is "no reasonable possibility" that she will recover and thus can be allowed to die.

WASHINGTON, May 6 In legislative proposals that call for major reforms to end bribery by American companies doing business abroad, Senator Frank Church has recommended that all major companies have outside directors to monitor questionable payments.
NEW ORLEANS, May 6 Two large grain companies were fined a total of $430,000 in Federal court today after pleading no contest to conspiracy charges in systematic thefts of grain from foreign commerce.
The American Basketball Association announced yesterday that it would "terminate" the troubled Virginia Squires franchise if it could not pay its substantial outstanding debts by Monday.

Raun MacKinnon, who is opening for Marc Allen Trujillo at Reno Sweeney's through Sunday, overshadows the star performer rather decisively. Mr. Trujillo, a pop singer with a narrow emotional range and a somewhat thin voice, has a recently negotiated recording contract to his credit.

New observations bearing on how ozone is broken down and replenished in the stratosphere have raised the possibility that fluorocarbons, used in spray cans and air-conditioning systems, may be depleting the protective ozone layer at a far slower rate than was supposed.
Robert J. Levin, a writer who specialized in the subjects of sex, marriage and family relationships, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his home at 222 East 35th Street. He was 55 years old.

George L. Shinn, chairman of the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking house, warned yesterday that unless stockbrokers got together to develop a proposed national stock market, the Securities and Exchange Commission would do it for them.

TEL AVIV, May 6 The Israeli Government has given a foreign company a partnership in a promising oilfield that is being developed in occupied Egyptian territory in the southern Sinai region, according to a high Government source.

The May delivery of potato futures contracts yesterday jumped the daily limit of 50 points to close at 9.70 cents a pound, up from 9.20 cents. Today is the last trading day for the volatile May contracts and all daily price limits are off.

The Transit Authority is continuing to pay a cost-of-living raise to its 34,000 unionized workers despite a ruling from the State Attorney General that such payments are in violation of the state's wage freeze law.

Tessie O'Shea, the British musical-comedy performer, will star in "Something's Afoot," described as a musical "whodunit," which will be presented at the Lyceum Theater on May 27, after a series of previews.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 Nine people, all policemen or private security guards, were murdered today in a bizarre incident that police here attributed to an apparent act of vengeance rather than a leftist guerrilla attack.

OTTAWA, May 6 Canada and the United States will work together in regulating fishing operations off both coasts of the two countries following claims in Ottawa and Washington to control of economic resources up to 200 miles from shore.
BARCELONA, Spain, May 6 A line of 60 people leaned against a block of houses on the Calle de Entenza yesterday evening looking fixedly across the busy street.

Raul Julia. This weekend people are going to come out of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center having seen Joseph Papp's somber, tawdry and yet magnificent production of the BrechtWeill "Threepenny Opera" and ask: "Who is that man?" That man is Raul Julia and he is playing, with a brooding intensity, the leading role of Mack the Knife.

O'Brien of various charges of misconduct, law-enforcement officials at all levels from police to courts can get back to work on a number of investigations that have been in a state of confusion in Suffolk County.
Soaring fourth-quarter television prices are not only driving agencies and their clients up the wall, they are also forcing far more serious consideration of other media than in the past.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market ended mixed yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

PRESIDENT FORD'S Labor-Management Committee is back in business, but it is no longer the President's committee. The 16 top corporate and union executives who make up the panel have cut their formal tie to the Administration and are now holding periodic meetings on thir own to seek consensus on issues of basic policy.

Rabbi Bernard Heller, scholar, author, teacher and lecturer, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 425 Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it planned to sell at auction 780,000 ounces of gold approximately every six weeks for the next two years, starting with an auction June 2.

ST. CATHERINE'S MONASTERY, Israeli-Occupied Sinai The Greek Orthodox monks who live in this ancient monastery deep in the southern Sinai Mountains closed their doors for a brief respite the other day after an invasion of tourists that one monk described, only half in jest as "our busiest fortnight in 1,000 years."

ALBANY, May 6 Peter A.A. Berle, who took office today as Acting Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said that his first order of business was to gain the confidence of the department's 3,000 employees and "to see if we can get this institution functioning."

More couples than ever appear to be postponing childbearing. According to Dr. Charles Westoff, director of the Office of Population Research at Princeton University, 13 percent of the married or formerly married women aged 25 to 29 in 1960 were childless. By last year the percentage had risen to 21.

The Treasury Department is expected to announce soon, perhaps today, that banks and savings and loan institutions with Government accounts may not pay dues to social clubs or organizations that exclude women or minorities.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose shares are the most widely held of any corporation, rarely gets rave notices from Wall Street.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 6 Switching back to their running offense after a couple of long-ball victories, the New York Yankees com pleted a three-game sweep of the California Angels tonight with a 4-2 victory.

The League of Women Voters, which has accepted men as members in the last two years, considered dropping "Women" from its name yesterday, but finally voted overwhelmingly to keep the old name after deciding that it was more valuable than it was sexist.

Donald V. Seibert, chairman and chief executive officer of the J.C. Penney Company, confirmed yesterday published reports that three Penney executives had recently been discharged for alleged wrongdoing.

WASHINGTON, May 6 A joint House-Senate conference committee agreed today to a target ceiling of Federal spending of $413.3 billion, a figure that is $17.5 billion higher than President Ford proposed but about $10 billion spent if all Federal programs were continued unchanged.
One of the three principals at the Friends Seminary on East 16th Street in Manhattan has filed a complaint alleging that she has been dismissed, as of next semester, because of her sex and age.

Sarah Bernhardt can be seen this weekend in the role of Queen Elizabeth I. Her voice tremulous, her arms outstretched, she portrays the strong-willed Queen of England, grieving over the lifeless body of Robert Devereux. Earl of Essex, the man she loved, but ordered put to death.
Piles of garbage in the four-day-old strike of building service employees continued to rise yesterday, and so did complaints from tenants and apartment-house owners.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Postal Service announced today that it would commemorate the signing of the Declaration of Independence by issuing a special 13cent stamp in Philadelphia July 4.

SANFORD, N.C. Just after Jimmy Carter won the Democratic primary in Pennsylvania, Mayor Roy Stewart of Sanford was quick to say he was very pleased, but the victory was not so important to him that he did not talk first about the weather, the plight of the state's farmers, the 27 days without a drop of rain.

Brown Jr., to stop Mr. Carter and achieve a brokered, "backroom" nomination at Madison Square Garden in July.

Women. This week's success story is about a book that was not really written, but rather evolved. Even its begetters young women; married, single, in-between are a bit hazy about the details. WASHINGTON The Republican Party is in trouble these days because it is playing its worst cards. Its strengths are that it has the Presidency, the economy is recovering and the nation is at peace for the first time in many years, but the G.O.P. seems determined to attack its own strengths.

IT is difficult to imagine not having tomatoes as a staple in our diet. We use them the most everyday in sauces, soups and ketchup, not to mention in salads and freshly sliced. Industry scientists suggested yesterday that recently revised estimates of atmospheric chem istry may reduce the predicted effects of fluorocarbons upon the protective ozone layer, "nearly to zero," and that therefore an early ban on their, use in spray cans was unnecessary.

With the reverence of conservationists displaying a whooping crane, the Offtrack Betting Corporation devoted a news conference yesterday to a horseplayer who had won $128,844 on a $3 bet.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, despite a larger budget and staff is processing fewer complaints than a year ago and the number of pending cases is approaching a record of 120,000, a Congressional committee reported today.

Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' third baseman, known as "Mr. Hustle" for his fierce competitiveness on the baseball field, was named yesterday as the sixth recipient of the Roberto Clemente Award, given annually to the player who best exemplifies the game of baseball on and off the field.

Stiff competition in the American domestic communications satellite business, accompanied by risks of near-term overcapacity, is expected to intensify after today's planned launching of a Comstar satellite. It is built to handle as many as 14,000 telephone conversations at one time.

"You have to love your work to stay in this business," Dr. Wallace F. Knight, a veterinarian, said during a round of "barn calls" the other day. A bull has injured Dr. Knight's back, a falling horse has crushed his leg, and a buffalo has kicked him in the head. Dr. Knight, like the few other large-animal veterinarians in Hunterdon County, is a necessity in the heart of New Jersey's livestock industry.

A one-act comic piece, it was preceded by Gian Carlo Menotti's terse melodrama "The Medium."

Charles Reznikoff's spare lines have been with us longer than most poets influenced by him have been alive. Eighty-one years old when he died in January, a central figure and elder statesman of that group of poets labelled "objectivist," he remained austerely beyond fashion, committed as ever to that which Louis Zukofsky noted about his work in Poetry magazine in 1931, "the sincerity which has seen, considered and weighed."

Lightning is one of nature's most awesome destructive forces. New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation loses about $200 million a year in emergency and outpatient care to people who do not pay, according to a corporation spokesman and an audit by Arthur Levitt, the State Comptroller.

WASHINGTON, May 16-- Five years ago, President Nixon coined the term Health Maintenance Organization to describe prepaid health groups --those organized medical services that allow a family to pay one set fee for almost all its medical care.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 16-- Iranian security forces killed at least 11 alleged terrorists here today after three Iranian security officials were assassinated in the capital early this morning, highly placed sources close to the Teheran police reported.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) --The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has asked the Justice Department to turn over a previously undisclosed "assassination file" of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Criticism of Israel by Jews and non-Jews is causing considerable uneasiness among many Jewish leaders in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 16-- Military intelligence agents have violated the rights of United States citizens in the agents' investigations of domestic political and protest groups, and in the process have threatened "to violate the traditional and legal restraints which govern the use of military forces in the civilian community," the staff of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has concluded.

It's a regrettably short docking for "H.M.S. Pinafore," the third and last of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas being presented on the D'Oyly Carte's American tour; she opened yesterday afternoon at the Uris Theater, and will sail out again after the Wednesday performance.

Eddie Palmieri was the top winner for the second year in a row at the second annual Latin N.Y. Music Awards ceremony last night. The awards, chosen by readers of Latin N.Y. magazine from a list selected by a nominating committee, are the principal form of noncommercial recognition for Latin musicians in this country. They were presented at the Beacon Theater.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, May 17--The Lebanese capital and its suburbs went through one of the most violent days of the 13-month civil war yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 16 --Ever since Cleopatra sailed her barge down the Nile, yachting has attracted royalty. Today Prince Henrik of Denmark served on the crew aboard Jesse Philips's Charisma in the Stamford-Denmark Friendship Race on blustery Long Island Sound.

A man walked slowly north on Seventh Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets. He shuffled, really, scarcely lifting his feet. He kept his eyes focused downward through the subway gratings in the sidewalk. Now and again he stopped. He bent down and shaded his eyes, trying to decide whether the flash of silver he had seen in the debris 10 feet below was a coin.

Last fall, with several members of the Yale Class of 1965, I returned to the chill of New Haven to mark, perfunctorily, the tenth year of our graduation. We had come of age during the civil rights movement of the mid1960's, but before the days of rage and drugs. We had been nurtured, politically, in the bosom of Democratic liberalism, and we took the rhetoric of our liberal mentors seriously.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16-- In these days of frenetic Presidential primary campaigning, Ronald Reagan usually appears to be marching to a different drummer.

WASHINGTON, May 16-- Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who for eight years has been the main architect of American foreign policy, said in an interview released today that even if President Ford won the November election, he would prefer to leave office.

NEW HAVEN, May 16 (AP) --Consumer activism and demands for the accountability of private business are preferable to government regulation or intrusion, Yale University's president, Kingman Brewster Jr., said today.

Because the emphasis in most contemporary jazz groups is directed toward solo performances, ensemble style tends to be minimized. So it is refreshing to find that the trio led by Warren Chiasson at Gregory's, 63d Street at First Avenue, bases its performances on a distinctive blend of Mr. Chiasson's vibraharp and Chuck Wayne's electric guitar, backed by Wilber Little's bass.

Detectives continued their investigation yesterday into the murder of Beverly Manol., the wife of a prominent Springfield, N.J., lawyer, who was stabbed and bludgeoned to death in her home Friday morning.

A leading stockbroker, caught up in a rate war in which his biggest institutional customers have exacted commission reductions of 50 percent and more, gleefully remarked the other day, "Now it's our turn to get some rate cuts."
Ronald Reagan made gains during the weekend that will keep him ahead of President Ford in the delegate count, regardless of what happens in the Maryland and Michigan primaries on Tuesday.
ATLANTA, May 12--Up in Maryland this last week, Jimmy Carter suggested that those who are curious about the kind of President he might be "should look at the sort of Governor I was."

RALEIGH, N.C., May 16 (UPI)--Sue Roberts, in her first victory in more than a year, shot a two-under par 70 today to win the $45,000 American Defender Classic, a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

ZOLDER, Belgium, May 16 (UPI)--Niki Lauda of Austria, still racing with painful ribs after a tractor accident at his home last month, led from start to finish today in a Ferrari and won the Grand Prix of Belgium.

Solicitor General Robert Bork is reportedly urging the Justice Department to file a friend of the court brief asking the Supreme Court: (1) to overturn the Federal District Court's order in the Boston school desegregation case; and (2) to reconsider its ruling in the 1971 North Carolina case approving transportation (busing) as a remedy for unconstitutional discrimination against black schoolchildren. The recommendation is reckless, foolish and destructive.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 15-- No comment was immediately forthcoming from the Iranian Government about a report from Washington that the United States had told Iran it must share control over any nuclear fuel reprocessing plant set up in this country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16 --About 8,000 supporters of the equal rights amendment from 30 states--from Maine to California--convened in front of a statue of Abraham Lincoln here today and rallied for passage of a 24-word-long addition to the United States Constitution that one speaker called part of the "second American revolution."
LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) --Stringent guidelines for ministers exorcizing evil spirits are recommended in a Methodist church study published here.
LOS ANGELES, May 16 (AP)--Kathy Howard of Oklahoma City took first place last night in the United States Olympic women's gymnastics trials. She will lead a sixwoman team to Montreal.
RENSSELAERVILLE, N.Y., May 16--Atomic scientists and United Nations diplomats turned up some unexpected political and ethical considerations at a weekend meeting here on nuclear issues.

WASHINGTON, May 16--The Senate Banking Committee unanimously urged the Federal Government today to "seriously consider" ending its $2.3 billion in annual, seasonal loans if New York City failed to maintain its three-year wage freeze.

ALBANY, May 15--With just a little bit of self-pity legislative leaders here are examining a range of strategies to try to salvage their vital expense allowances, popularly known as "Luius," which were declared unconstitutional in court again this week.

FORT WORTH, May 16 (AP)--Lee Trevino, shaken and unsteady and with his game on the verge of collapse, parlayed a lucky break into a birdie that turned back Mike Morley and enabled him to win the Colonial national invitation golf tournament today. It was the first victory of his pro career in Texas.

As the State Legislature rushes toward hoped-for adjournment at the end of this month, there are growing signs that the lawmakers--and the Carey Administration --are determined to sidestep two of the most critical issues facing the current session, issues that vitally affect the future of New York City and communities throughout the state, both of which were referred to in the Senate Banking Committee's report released yesterday. They are public employee pensions and rent control.

New York City's new Health Systems Agency, set up under Federal law to make sure health care is delivered efficiently, indicated yesterday that one of its first targets would be what it called the excessive number of open-heart surgery units in hospitals here.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP)-Janet Guthrie raced through the final phase of her rookie test in today's rainshortened practice session for the Indianapolis 500, and she was cleared to make a historic qualification attempt for the 33-car field.

Officers of eight newspaper unions met with leaders of the Newspaper Guild yesterday and promised to respect picket lines of the guild if it carried through its threat to strike The New York Post at 5 P.M. Thursday.

LONDON, May 16-Harold E. McCafferty received two gentlemanly tax inspectors a few weeks ago at his Black Cap Pub, a sprawling establishment in northwest London known for transvestite floor shows. Their visit, to check the pub's books, is a normal enough occurrence for many British businessmen. But what followed 15 minutes later was not so normal.

LOS ANGELES, May 17 (AP) A spokesman for Ronald Reagan denied today a report indicating that the former California Governor paid no Federal income tax in 1970. But he declined to say how much Mr. Reagan did pay.

Aerial tramway service connecting Manhattan with the city's newest urban community on Roosevelt Island was formally inaugurated yesterday with champagne and public expressions of hope for the city's future.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 Libya, a supporter of the most extreme elements within the Palestinian camp, today openly entered the Lebanese scene in an attempt to mediate between Syria and the various leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

MEXICO CITY, May 17 (AP) Mexican tire company executives say they paid the former manager of the Mexican Chamber of Rubber Industries for his part in obtaining Government approval of price increases for Mexican tires, the Attorney General's office said today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 As champions for the preceding two seasons the Philadelphia Flyers had not been well-liked outside of their own rink. Because the team was based in the United States, some people in the National Hockey League had considered the Flyers inappropriate custodians of the Stanley Cup, the symbol of supremacy in Canada's national sport.

Leontyne Price is one of America's national monuments. Her admirers apparently no more want her to change than they would want to see the Grand Canyon filled in and paved over. So there was general and vociferous rejoicing on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall when the soprano, in splendid form, gave a recital that reminded any who may have forgotten that hers is one of the premiere voices of our period.

Margaret Chubb Parsons, a trustee of the Newark Museum and of the Urban League of Essex County, which named its headquarters in her honor in 1971, died Sunday in New York Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J.

TRENTON, May 17 State Senate leaders were holding firm today to their plans to put the income-tax bill up for a vote Wednesday despite their inability to count on 21 affirmative votes, the minimum needed for passage.
CLEVELAND, May 17 Elston Howard stared morosely out at the rain steadily falling outside the Yankees' hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 17 President Ford officially revised the Federal Election Commission today, apparently clearing the way for resumption of Federal campaign subsidies tomorrow and ending an eight-week freeze on such payments.

James E. Kenney, oldest living New York City member of the Friars Club, the fraternal and charitable show-business organization, died Friday in the City Hospital Center, at Elmhurst, Queens. His age was 86,

SOMERSET, Ky., May 17 (AP) John Sherman Cooper said in an interview with a radio station here today that he is resigning as Ambassador to East Germany. Mr. Cooper, who will be 75 years old in August, said he had told President Ford he would resign because he felt it was time for a younger man to take the post.

TOKYO, May 17 The Japanese, who according to nationalist myth had a bicentennial birthday 2,400 years ago, are marking the United States' 200th anniversary these days with more enthusiasm than many Americans show.

WASHINGTON, May 17 The United States continued to be a large exporter of capital in the first quarter of this year through purchases of foreign securities and bank loans to foreigners, preliminary figures on the nation's international transactions disclosed today.

North Sea oil production is surpassing forecasts made a year ago but is stil nowhere near so substantial as expected originally by this time, Lord Balogh, deputy chairman of the British National Oil Corporation, said in a recent interview in New York.

Rafael Fruhbeck de Burgos, the Spaniard who took charge of the Montreal Symphony last fall, brought the orchestra to Carneige Hall last night for its first New York appearance.

KALANDIA, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, May 17?An 18-year-old Arab student was shot and killed by Israeli soldiers fleeing an angry mob today as riots continued on the West Bank of the Jordan River for the third day.

WASHINGTON May 17 The political committees set up by corporations to channel campaign contributions to favored candidates have invested more than four times as much money in President Ford as they have in his Republican challenger, Ronald Reagan, in 1976.

Three murals on the walls of the Oak Bar at the Plaza Hotel by the American painter Everett Shinn have been purchased by the current owners of the Plaza, Western International Hotels, it was announced yesterday. Western Interna tional bought the hotel itself from the Sonesta Corporation last year for $25 million. The murals were not part of the sale.
WEST POINT, N. Y. May 17 The lounge in Grant Hall carries pleasant memories for generations of West Point graduates as the site of longawaited visits with family members and girlfriends.

The J.C. Penney Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, had a sharp recovery in the first quarter, with net income of $29.9 million in the 13 weeks ended May 1 against $5.1 million in the same 1975 period, Donald V. Seibert, chairman and chief executive officer, said yesterday at the annual meeting. The quarter's net was equal to 47 cents a share, up from 9 cents a share.

Management of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, no longer confronted by a maze of financial problems and stockholder antagonism, told shareholders at their annual meeting today at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden that the "most difficult" problem confronting the company now was providing energy at prices it customers could accept as reasonable.

WASHINGTON, May 17 A House banking subcommittee cleared today a bill designed to restrict the operations of foreign banks in this country, putting them on basically the same footing as United States banks.
Prince Alexis A. Droutzkoy, a member of the White Russian colony in New York, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 1020 Fifth Avenue.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the counter market finished lower yesterday in slower trading.

A plea for new state legislation to enable 400,000 aged, blind and disabled poor in the state to receive a 6.4 percent cost-of-living increase July 1 under the Supplemental Security Income program was made public yesterday by the Community Council of Greater New York.

Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel ruled yesterday that the arguments of East Side community leaders were insufficient to delay further the construction of a subway station at 63d Street. John Alexander Messersmith, the million-dollar former free agent, better known as Andy, finally got his act together for the Braves in Houston last night. The 30year-old righthander tossed a seven-hiller at the Houston Astros in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader and picked a 3-2 victory, his first as a Brave, after four straight losses.

EAST BERLIN, May 17 (Reuters) East German leaders today welcomed Mikhail A. Suslov, a member of the ruling Politburo as the chief foreign delegate to their ninth party congress, which begins tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 17 Governor Corey's press secretary, Robert W. Laird, is leaving the job he has held since the beginning of the Carey administration to become a deputy commissioner in the State Commerce Department, the Governor's office announced today.
DENVER, May 17 (AP) Arnold Palmer, the golfer, and three companions set out in a business jet today to try for a round-the-world speed record.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Reporting that Americans smoked a record 601 billion to 603 billion cigaretttes last year, the Federal Trade Commission announced today an investigation to determine whether the tobacco industry was encouraging smoking with unfair advertising.

SAN ANGELO, Tex., May 17 (AP) Jake Jacobsen, a onetime aide to President Johnson, pleaded no contest today to a theft charge involving an $825,000 loan and was immediately given seven years probation.
WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., May 17 (AP) The United States Chess Federation has decided not to participate in an Arab-sponsored "Against Israel Chess Olympic."
ROME, May 17 With the Italian election campaign now under way, the Roman Catholic Church is intensifying its efforts to persuade Italian voters to reject the Communist Party.
Billie Jean King, Chris Evert and Rosemary Casals were named yesterday to the Federation Cup team by the United States Tennis Association.

Frantic trading in May potato futures on May 7, when the contracts expired, wiped out many traders who were long on Maine "round whites" and apparently sent short sellers scrambling for $10 million worth of potatoes. The record-breaking pace in the trading of commodity futures continued through April, according to the latest report issued by the Futures Industry Association.

The Sharon Steel Corporation, a unit of the NVF Company, announced yesterday approval by its directors of a $216 million bid to extend its interest in foremost-McKesson Inc., to 77.9 percent.

James A. Baker 3d, former Under Secretary of Commerce, asserted yesterday that investment tax incentives are essential if American industry is to be capable of meeting strong competition for world markets.

WASHINGTON, May 17 The Federal Energy Administration wants to modify the special relief for certain small refiners that Congress wrote into the 1975 Energy Policy and Conservation Act. It also wants to extend the modified relief to all small refiners.

Alvin Ailey and Walter Terry will be hosts at 9:30 o'clock tonight at Roseland, where leading dancers from Broadway, ballet and modern dance, will teach ballroom dance at a special benefit for the Association of American Dance Companies.

BALTIMORE, May 16 In the middle of one of the television commercials shown here for Jimmy Carter in the final weekend of the Maryland primary campaign, the cover of last week's Time magazine fills the screen with a portrait of the candidate.
TRALEE, Ireland, May 17 (AP) A Briton and a crew of four set out in a leather boat tonight, hoping to prove that an Irish monk discovered the New World nine centuries before Columbus.

Stuart Schulberg, who has been producer of NBC's "Today" show since 1968, has received a new assignment as an executive producer of NBC news documentaries, and will be succeeded on the two-hour morning program within two weeks by Paul Friedman. TRENTON, May 17 Several thousand teachers from throughout the state took a day off from classes today to lobby for passage of a personal income tax that would provide full financing for public school education in New Jersey.

The Defense Intelligence Agency, the target of much recent Congressional inquiry, got news of a new director yesterday with the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Samuel V. Wilson, a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency. If confirmed, he will succeed Lieut. Gen. Daniel O. Graham, who resigned last fall when James R. Schlesinger was replaced as Secretary of Defense.

The Bicentennial Barge, a floating exhibition of historical memorabilia dealing with the political and cultural character of New York State from 1765 to 1789, will be launched on June 3 at 1 P.M. at the South Street Seaport Museum in Manhattan.
With some reluctance and much chagrin, Bill Talbert made it official yesterday; he is no longer the chairman and director of the United States Open tennis tournament.

ALBANY, May 19 The state's commercial bankers were hurt by their own stubbornness in seeking to defeat the bill that would allow savings bank checking accounts according to several legistators and Carey administration officials. The bill gained final passage in the State Senate last night.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) Senate-House conferees agreed in principle today to make permanent the sports antiblackout television law, but not before Senator John O. Pastore upbraided his colleagues for having accused him of having made a deal with football's commissioner, Pete Rozelle.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 19 Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a 48-year-old New Jersey surgeon who has been referred to as Dr. X, has been indicted on charges of murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell a decade ago.

BILBAO, Spain, May 14 In the Basque country, where ethnic separatism and a high degree of labor militancy combined to produce the sharpest opposition in the 36 years of Franco's dictatorship, the liberalization that followed the general's death last November has been least felt.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 19 Reconciliation talks between Egypt and Syria were postponed today without explanation shortly before they were to have begun here.

WASHINGTON May 19 (AP) The number of persons on state and local welfare rolls rose to 1,002,629 last January, exceeding a million for the first time in more than four and a half years, the Government reported today.

DACCA, Bangladesh, May 19 (AP) About 100 armed people crossed into eastern Bangladesh from India yesterday and attacked the frontier post at Matirban with the support of mortar fire from Indian border forces, Bangladesh officials said today.

The Housing Council of New York, a coalition of 14 real estate groups from various parts of the state, called yesterday on the Legislature and Governor Carey to enact a three-year phasing out of New York City's rent control and rent stabilization programs. Such programs limit rent increases in a total of 1.3 million apartments.

It's not hard to announce an impending birth these days. The maternity sections of department stores and the specialty boutiques are inundated with T-shirts that read "Baby," "Stork Club," "Construction Below" and "Je Suis Enceinte" (French for "I am pregnant").

YORKTOWN, Va., May 19 President Giscard d'Estaing paid an hour's visit to the site here of the decisive battle of the Revolutionary War, and said that Yorktown would "forever remind us, friends to this day, of what we can accomplish together in the name of liberty."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19 A United Nations committee today adopted a set of recommendations stressing the Palestinians' "right to return" to their homeland.

GORI, U.S.S.R. Open tributes to Stalin, which have been virtually obliterated throughout most of the Soviet Union in the last 20 years, continue to thrive in Georgia, and especially here in Gori, where he was born.

WASHINGTON, May 19 Richard Aurelio, former Deputy Mayor of New York, has registered with the Justice Department as a foreign agent in connection with his work as a representative of the manufacturer of the Concorde supersonic airliner.

The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers. The reports show a large number of company officials exercising options to buy stock.

WASHINGTON, May 19 The Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a lower Federal court decision requiring that suspects called to testify before grand juries must be given the same right to remain silent and to have a lawyer that the police must give to suspects in custody.

"When Sigmund Freud was a young medical student, he wrote a significant histological paper for which he dissected 400 eels. Freud went to the trouble of dissecting 400 eels to make sure his conclusions were founded on fact."

The New York Philharmonic's 12th season of free concerts in the city's parks will be opened with a gala Bicentennial program on July 4 in Central Park's Sheep Meadow, with Leonard Bernstein conducting. For the first time, the Exxon Corporation will be a principal funder of these concerts, which in the 11 previous years were supported by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee.

MOSCOW, May 19 (Reuters) The official Tass press agency today dismissed Western allegations of growing Soviet military spending as propaganda intended to insure higher defense budgets in certain North Atlantic Treaty countries.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 19 (UPI) The Nebraska Supreme Court refused today to hold the manufacturer of the anesthetic drug Innovar responsible for brain damage to the mother of three children who has been technically alive but unconscious for the last five years.
Governor Carey has announced the appointment of a special committee to coordinate the efforts of New Yorkers in providing relief for the victims of the recent earthquake in northern Italy.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California arrived here today from Baltimore looking for a way to turn his solid victory over Jimmy Carter in the Maryland primary into a winning streak that could alter the course of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

RENO, May 19 Ronald Reagan came to the gambling state of Nevada today to try to change his luck after suffering heavy losses yesterday in Republican Presidential primary elections in Michigan and Maryland.
TRENTON, May 19 The New Jersey Senate tonight rejected a proposed state income tax for the sixth time in two years.

LUANDA, Angola, May 19 Angola's Prime Minister said last night that his Government's foreign policy was based on nonalignment with any bloc but at the same time on preferential relations with what he called the socialist countries, particularly Cuba.

The news divisions of ABC, CBS and NBC have all turned down the request of the Public Broadcasting Service for permission to carry their pool coverage of the political conventions this summer without charge.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 19 (Reuters) The more conservative United Bermuda Party today emerged as victor in this self-governing British colony's general elections, but saw its majority reduced in the House of Assembly.
KHARTOUM, Sudan, May 18 (AP) President Gaafar alNimeiry warned his ministers and legislators today either to give up alcoholic drinks or resign.

OSLO, May 19 (Reuters) The Icelandic and British Foreign Ministers had a surprise meeting here last night on their countries' dispute over fishing rights. British sources said, however, that there had been no change in the positions of the two nations.
Mayor Beame, predicting that the summer of 1976 would be "the most exciting for New York City in our lifetime," yesterday opened a campaign to welcome the Democratic National Convention.
OSLO, May 19 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight for the annual conference of North Atlantic Treaty Organization foreign ministers.

DETROIT, May 19 (UPI) The Ford Motor company said today that it was recalling nearly one-half million current-model Ford and Lincoln-Mercury cars because quick acceleration might cause the gas pedal to stick.

Both production and stocks of gasoline in the United States fell last week, according to statistics announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 19 (AP) The State Board of Medical Examiners censured today and placed on a year's probation a white doctor accused of removing freshly sewn stitches from the arm of a young black patient who was unable to pay the doctor's $25 fee.

WASHINGTON, May 19 A new phase in the nationwide testing of flu vaccine began today as doctors and nurses at the National Institutes of Health gave volunteers injections of three types of vaccine that will be used against next winter's flu.

Kennedy.

The New York Times and CBS News polled 1,840 Michigan voters yesterday as they left the polling places. Of these, 1,002 were Republicans and 838 were Democrats.

PEORIA, Ill. Betty Goldstein, a young girl who thought so fast that she tripped over her words, and who had to be given a nonspeaking role in her high school play, left Peoria more than three decades ago. She returned in 1963 for her 25th class reunion, a Smith College graduate, wife, mother and just-published author. The name on her book jacket was Betty Friedan, and the book was called "The Feminine Mystique."

Madison Avenue Hospital, a 117-bed profit-making facility, has been informed that because of life-threatening fire and health violations, it is no longer eligible to receive Medicare funds. The cutoff of funds, effective June 8, is expected to result in the closing of the hospital, which has been targeted for closure by city and state officials for years.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (Reuters)-A strong quake shook an area of the Southern Pacific Ocean today, the United States Geological Survey reported here. Estimates put it on or near the island of New Britain, a spokesman said.

MANILA, May 23 A Philippine Air Lines jet seized Friday by six hijackers exploded in flames early today in an exchange of fire between the gunmen and attacking Philippine troops. Three of the hijackers and 10 of the hostages died in the battle. The three other hijackers were captured.
MEMPHIS, May 23 (AP) Gibby Gilbert, chipping in the par he needed on the 17th hole, scored a four-stroke victory today in the $200,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis Golf Classic.

FREEHOLD, May 23 Ronald L. Sage, a 32-year-old Freehold lawyer who had hoped to argue a landmark case to void state laws against the personal use of marijuana in homes, has failed in his appeal by winning in the courtroom.

Martha L. Gorowitz, a cash-compensation officer in the human resources department of the Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., was married at noon yesterday to R. Scot Perlin. He is with the Australia/NewZealand/South Pacific desk in the Asia division of the Bankers Trust Company.

AGANA, Guam, May 23 (UPI) Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo said today that a typhoon that struck Guam over the weekend had caused more than $300 million in damage, leaving 80 percent of the island's buildings in ruins, three persons dead and 60 injured.

MISSION VIEJO, Calif., May 23 President Ford ventured today into oratorical territory heretofore occupied by Jimmy Carter when he discoursed on the Bible at a school sponsored by a fundamentalist Christian group.
PITTSBURGH, May 23 Horace W. Wilkie, Chief Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, died here today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) A Federal poll suggests that violent crime has not increased as much as many Americans may have feared.

EXOTIC GROOVE, At his keyboard in the New York Hilton Hotel's Kismet Lounge, Ben Dino's music adds to the escapist aspect of this atmospheric room, at the far end of the hotel's northside concourse on the main floor. A few steps down and you're on thick, Far East carpeting with clusters of tables, chairs and banquettes.

ALBANY, May 22 Construction of a new bridge across the Hudson River alongside the present Newburgh-Beacon Bridge will start next month, a year behind schedule. Since test borings began four years ago, the estimated cost of the new bridge has almost doubled, from $55 million to $107 million, with the possibility that the final cost will be even higher, according to the state Department of Transportation.

With little help from Washington, they stood up to massive political resistance and personal attack in their own communities. A book on their performance, by J.W. Peltason, is called "Fifty-Eight Lonely Men."

Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" has become something of an annual rite of spring with many choral groups. This 40-year-old scenic cantata, based on lusty medieval poems celebrating love and the rebirth of nature, seems especially appropriate for this time of year, and so it was not surprising that the Collegiate Chorale chose the work as its major offering Saturday night in Carnegie Hall.

ALBANY, May 24 In a move to bolster President Ford on the eve of six crucial primaries, 119 New York Republican delegates, or 77 percent of the state delegation, voted today to endorse the President.

The open, or crossover, primary, which has muddled the results in several states this spring, has a chance of doing more mischief today not only in Tennessee but also in Arkansas, Idaho and three more states thereafter. The crossover is that electoral quirk that allows a Democrat a vote in choosing the Republican candidate and a Republican a reciprocal privilege in the Democratic primary as long as each confines himself to one party's ballot.

In his recital in Town Hall on Thursday night, Jonathen Donnson gave a quite special performance of Schumann's "Dichterliebe." The tenor sang the 16-part song cycle with a light lyric voice that had plenty of room for nuance and color. His sensitivity to the text and musical phrase was constant, and his voice was consistently appealing. Together with Elizabeth Rodgers's fine playing of the piano part, Mr. Donnson's singing made the work an impressive experience.

The symbiosis between the specialist, who knows something but can't write it for a general audience, and the popularizer, who can writ to engage a wide readership, is an uneasy one. The specialist accuses the popularizer of glibness; the popularizer disdains the hermetic world of experts. New York City, which has offered a free college education to its citizens since 1847, is expected to bow to fiscal pressures and impose tuition in the City University by a vote tonight of a reluctant Board of Higher Education.

Cyril William Beaumont, the noted ballet historian and bookseller, died May 24 in a London hospital. He was 85 years old.

BOSTON, May 31 If you were wondering how some Boston fans would react tonight to the Red Sox's brawl with the Yankees earlier this month in New York, here's the answer: They threw things, such as exploding bombs, rocks, golf balls and the like.

WARSAW, May 31 (Reuters) The number of exit permits granted to people wishing to emigrate to West Germany has risen sharply since ratification of the Warsaw-Bonn agreement on payments and emigration in March, West German sources said here today.

Martha Mitchell, the outspoken estranged wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, died early yesterday at the Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 57 years old.

The computers and dazzling high-speed printers of The Associated Press relentlessly spill out something like three million words a day. At the same time, the news is rewritten, reedited and transmitted to millions more people in 100 foreign countries.

LIME ROCK, Conn., May 31 George Dyer of Woodside, Calif., is a 27-year-old Porsche Carrera driver who never had led a professional race since he began racing three years ago. Yet, at Lime Rock Park today, he slipped past an astounded Michael Keyser on the last lap, and won the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT race by a thousandth of a second.

Two young New York experts, Keith Garber and Carl Lindenman, won the Goldman pairs championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night, adding their names to a 46-year-list of champions that includes many of the greatest figures in the history of the game. In second position were Alan Sontag, one of the game's most formidable performers, and Harshad Shukla of New York City.

The maneuvering has started in the regular and reform ranks of the Democratic Party in Manhattan and Brooklyn for the patronage-laden posts of Surrogate the specialized court with jurisdiction over estates. JACKSON, Miss., May 31 (AP) After giving the charter airline a taste of its own medicine, a county judge today dropped a legal action that had grounded a World Airways jet for more than 36 hours.

The Atlanta Braves took their flamboyant owner, Ted Turner, off the hook last night by beating the San Diego Padres, 9-1, in Atlanta Stadium.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 1 (AP) Thailand rejected today a request by the United States that it be allowed to keep an electronic eavesdropping station in operation, and again ordered the American military to leave the country by July 20.

The first season of WNET/13's "Dance in America" series is concluded this evening at 9 with a documentary portrait of the Pennsylvania Ballet. Excerpts from the company's repertory are mixed with interviews, glimpses of rehearsal classes and a rather detailed history of dancing in Pennsylvania. based on the theory that the history of American dancing is rooted there. That theory is at the very least, arguable.

A group representing more more than 100 scientists and engineers, including five Nobel laureates, came out yesterday against regulations that would drastically "curtail and ultimately ban" the use of nuclear power. The group referred specifically to California's Proposition 15, which will be on the state's June 8 primary ballot.
"New York isn't all fun and games, there's also politics."

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Nearly two-thirds of state prison inmates have used drugs regularly and one-fourth were serving time for crimes committed while under the influence of drugs, a Census Bureau survey reported today.

The nation's commitment to law and order is to be tested soon in a Senate appropriations subcommittee as it considers what might otherwise appear to be a routine money bill. The measure is the appropriation bill for the new Legal Services Corporation, which is attempting to rescue the program from its present stagnation.

Memorial Day seemed to linger an extra day on Wall Street this year, as trading on the New York Stock Exchange slipped yesterday to the second lowest level of the year. The spring lethargy reached also to prices which, after a promising beginning ultimately closed down.

ALBANY, June 1 Legislative leaders were hopeful here today of final action on a plan to reorganize the City University's management and financing by the end of this week after the Board of Higher Education voted to impose tuition on all students tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Atomic energy specialists from 11 countries that are major exporters of nuclear technology began assembling in London today to discuss new safeguard mechanisms for curbing the spread of atomic weapons.

A silver trophy named after Robert Trent Jones, the golf-course architect, will be presented to the winner of the eighth annual Insurance Youth Classic tournament, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of the sponsors, the Independent Insurance Agents of America. Jones, who has designed more than 400 courses, was a scratch player in his teens before an ulcer forced him out of competition.
LOS ANGELES Atomic power, once assumed to be a simple answer to energy problems but now a matter of widespread controversy, will face a significant hurdle in California's primary next Tuesday.

Two prominent East Coast experts won two titles during the Eastern Regional Championships which ended Monday at the New York Hilton Hotel. Mike Moss of New York and Ken Cohen of Philadelphia, who had captured the Men's Pair title Friday, scored a second success Monday by winning the Mixed Teams. Moss played with his wife, Gail, and Cohen with Helen Smith, another Philadelphian.

Despite a .440 splurge by Billy Williams of the Oakland A's, Rico Carty of the Cleveland Indians continues to hold a commanding lead in the batting race among the American League's designated hitters.
WASHINGTON, June 1 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Citing alleged prosecutorial abuses by Maurice H. Nadjari, a special state prosecutor, the staff of a State Assembly committee has proposed major changes in the state's grand jury system.

WASHINGTON, June 1 They gave a party for Thomas Jefferson tonight at the National Gallery of Art, with a dinner that he might have eaten served at tables decorated with flowers that could have come from Monticello's gardens, and a fireworks display such as those he admired in Paris.

The New York City Planning Commission voted unanimously yesterday to adopt new procedures giving community boards a formal role for the first time in determining the use of land within their jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Striking down a nearly 100year-old Government practice, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Civil Service Commission may not bar resident aliens from Federal Civil Service jobs.

Described by his editor as "one of the more unique observers of Republican politics." John W. Dean 3d is going to join "the boys on the bus' for Rolling Stone magazine, covering the Republican National Convention and Presidential campaign as a special correspondent.
A series of brief but powerful thunderstorms swept through the New York City metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, wreaking an irregular pattern of havoc from northern New Jersey to Long Island.

The Steel Company of Canada announced yesterday that it planned to raise its bar prices on June 28 by between $16 and $25 a ton, depending on quality. The increases range from 7 to 8 percent for merchant bars and up to 9 percent for alloy bars, industry sources indicated.

PARIS, June 1 European Socialists, bogged down in quarrels stemming from the issue of whether to cooperate with Communists, have again postponed their long-delayed international congress scheduled for this summer.
OSLO, Norway, June 1 (AP) Britain and Iceland signed a temporary agreement today ending the seven-month dispute over fishing rights off Iceland.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Striking down a nearly 100year-old Government practice, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Civil Services Commission may not bar resident aliens from Federal Civil Service jobs.

MOSCOW, June 1 (AP) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, and President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines have agreed to establish diplomatic relations between their countries, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.
Steel production continued to rise and, in the week ended May 29, hit its highest level for the year to date, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The United States gave its tacit approval today to the latest Syrian military incursions into Lebanon but again warned Damascus not to increase its forces beyond Israel's tolerance.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The major reason that Jimmy Carter appears to be leading President Ford as the choice of the electorate at this point is the former Georgia Governor's overwhelming support among blacks.
The Suffolk County police arrested the woman friend and a business associate of a wealthy North Shore motorcycle dealer yesterday on charges of kidnapping and murdering the dealer.

The H.K. Porter Company, owner of 52 percent of the Missouri Portland Cement Company, has filed suit in Federal Court in St. Louis to compel Missouri Portland to seat two

Patrick J. Cunningham took a league of absence as Democratic state chairman yesterday until charges of bribery, conspiracy and tampering with evidence that had been brought against him are disposed of.

DETROIT, June 1 (AP) Michigan's doctors and hospitals, abandoned by commercial insurers, have announced that they are entering the insurance field themselves to provide protection against malpractice suits.
NEW DELHI, June 1 (Reuters) India, which has had a bumper crop, now has food grain stocks of about 14 millions tons, Jagjivan Ram, Minister of Food and Agriculture said yesterday.

And simply because it is about black women not just blacks and not just women it is a very humbling but inspiring thing for a white man to experience.
Almost without exception the major agencies, feeling the pinch for qualified account executives because of reduced training programs in recent years, are back on campus recruiting this year.
TOKYO, June 1 (AP) Two severe earthquakes struck a western part of China's Yunnan Province on Saturday, the Peking radio reported today.
"When you're talking about I.B.M.," a Wall Street analyst commented yesterday, "there's a hyperintensity of interest at all times in the investment community."
FORT MEADE, Md., June 1 (UPI) Fire forced the topsecret National Security Agency to turn to emergency power equipment today.
The New York City Board of Higher Education voted 7 to 1 last night to impose tuition at the City University next fall, drawing the curtain on a unique era in American education.

NEWARK, June 1 A banjo-picking psychiatrist from Tennessee demonstrated today the therapeutic effects of music to 500 professionals and laymen attending the opening day of the 25th annual conference of the New Jersey Association for Mental Health at the Robert Treat Hotel here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1 (Reuters) Two foreign correspondents who entered Cuba to report on last week's United Nations seminar on apartheid were denied exit visas after the meeting closed at the weekend, officials said today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund will auction 780,000 ounces of gold tomorrow amid signs of heavy interest on the part of market professionals.

TRENTON, June 1 The $2.85 billion state budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 was voted out of a joint legislative committee today and appeared to be headed for a bitter fight on the floor of the Legislature.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 1 A bomb exploded at the Plymouth Rock Shrine late tonight, but the police said that the monument to the Pilgrim landing in 1620 had not been damaged.
The four-year notes that the Federal Government will sell tomorrow will likely yield close to 7.65 percent, a rate somewhat lower than Wall Street guessed last week.

Environmental groups, organizations representing the elderly and consumer groups have been rating legislators based on voting records on bills the groups deem important, but in March when a group called Environmental Action headed its list of the "dirty dozen" with the name of the House minority leader, John J. Rhodes, and said he should be defeated for his poor record on ecological issues, Mr. Rhodes began a counterattack with the support of 101 other members.

LUMPKIN, Ga. The road disappears into pines draped with wisteria, whole groves and hillsides covered with heartrendering purple. Then the pines and vines fall away and there, just a few yards from the road, is a washed-out gully that goes straight down 150 feet and fingers across the low slopes a quarter of a mile.

Mayor Beame signed a bill into law yesterday legalizing pinball machines in New York City. But it will remain at "tilt" for 60 days while the Consumer Affairs Department develops licensing regulations.

WEST POINT, June 1 Cadet Timothy Ringgold, acting "individually and on behalf of all other similarly situated cadets," filed suit against the United States Military Academy in Federal Court today to seek elimination of the honor code.

"BOHEMIAN SUMMER" Such a title does not refer to warm months ahead in contemporary Greenwich Village. This is a new play a romantic drama derived from Henri Murger's Scenes de la Vie de Boheme," which gives previews tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and opens officially on Friday.
SEOUL, South Korea They call themselves the half-persons. The Koreans politely call them the mixed-race people. Pearl S. Buck, the author who wrote about the Orient, called them Amerasians.

Fewer meat specials and sales in food stores throughout the city pushed grocery prices up again last week, the Department of Consumer Affairs announced. The cost of a market basket of food went from $70.92 for the week ending May 21 to $71 for the same groceries purchased during the week ending May 28. That represented a 0.1 percent increase.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The major reason that Jimmy Carter appears to be leading President Ford as the choice of the electorate at this point is the former Georgia Governor's overwhelming support among blacks.

MEMPHIS Dedrick (Teddy) Withers was elected to the Tennessee House of Representatives in the fall of 1974, defeating a powerful, two-term white incumbent and becoming, at 22, the second youngest representative in the history of the state.

Outside of the fact that Joe Torre hit two home runs, the New York Mets spent, another cheerless evening at Shea Stadium last night as John Candelaria of the Pittsburgh Pirates stopped them, 3-2, on six hits and 12 strikeouts.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that employees of the Federal Government have the same rights as privately employed workers to have full trials in a Federal district court when they file Title VII job discrimination complaints.
