Then the pines and vines fall away and there, just a few yards from the road, is a washed-out gully that goes straight down 150 feet and fingers across the low slopes a quarter of a mile.

WASHINGTON, June 1-The Secretaries of State and the Treasury expressed annoyance today at the "last-minute" rejection by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Nairobi, Kenya, of the United States proposal for a new international resources bank.

PARIS, June 1 (UPI) John Newcombe, hardly looking like the three-time Wimbledon champion, lost to Juan Gisbert of Spain, 2-6, 7-6, 7-5, 6-4, in a major upset in the first round of the $210,000 French open tennis championships.
DEVON, Pa., June 1 New Horizon, the only mount in the field to clear 13 jumps, won the fault-and-out class in the intermediate jumper division today at the Devon Horse Show.
There never has been a greater need for professionally trained American historians than today, and never has there been a time when so many historians were seeking employment.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation has called on the Beame administration to plan an additional $150 million worth of budget cuts in the coming year to be kept as standby protection against various "soft spots" in New York City's austerity plan.

Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California claimed a victory in Rhode Island last night on the basis of the narrow plurality achieved by the uncommitted slate in that state's Democratic Presidential primary election yesterday, even though some of the uncommitted delegates reportedly support former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) New England and the rest of the northeast receive considerably less procurement funding from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration than the Sunbelt states, according to a Library of Congress study.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 (AP) Attorney General Bill Baxley said today a witness had admitted he incorrectly identified one of the three white men he said had forced a black truck driver to leap to his death in a river 19 years ago.
JERUSALEM, June 1 (Reuters) The governor of the Bank of Israel has called for cuts in all spending except defense because of Israel's "desperate" economic situation.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Two major unions in the textile and men's apparel field voted today to merge. At the same time their leaders announced plans for a new drive to organize workers in those industries in the largely unorganized South and Southwest.
Continued concern over increasing interest rates weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in sluggish trading.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) Traffic crashes across the nation during the Memorial Day weekend took 442 livs, exceeding the estimate of the National Safety Council.

The Kansas City Chiefs traded Otis Taylor, the team's leading career receiver, to the Houston Oilers yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice. In his 11 years with the Chiefs, Taylor made 410 catches for 7,306 yards and 57 touchdowns. That ranks him second behind Fred Biletnikoff of Oakland among active American Football Conference receivers, and 21st on the National Football League career list.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 1 (AP) Vinny Giles conquered the Scottish winds today and moved another step toward winning the British Amateur for the second straight year.
Contract talks between Trans World Airlines and representatives of its 5,000 cabin and flight attendants and service workers continued yesterday in the face of a midnight Friday strike deadline.

Prof. Alfred Levine of Richmond College on Staten Island was so frustrated by the llthhour shutdown of the college, along with the rest of City University, that he told the 25 students in his physics class to meet on the 6:45 ferry out of St. George, S.I., last night for their final examination.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 1 Jai-alai opened in Bridgeport tonight, half a year late and full of promise that it was rid of the scandal on which this fast-moving Basque game had been stumbling in trying to get started in Connecticut.

A 48-year-old investment counselor convicted of trying to "fence" a million dollars worth of stolen stock was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to 18 months' imprisonment and fines totaling $20,000.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Demands for disciplinary action against Representative Wayne L. Hays mounted today, spurted by pressure from constitutents of House members who had spent the holiday weekend in their Congressional districts.

The 600 tenants of Willoughby Walk, an apartment complex in the Fort Greene district of Brooklyn, began a rent strike yesterday to protest the alleged failure of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to maintain the property adequately.
Hugo E. Johnson, president of the American Iron Ore Association of Cleveland from 1958 to 1975, died Monday in University Hospital, Cleveland, after a long illness. His age was 68.

The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its group of professional magazines, headed by Modern Medicine, to Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a publishing concern. The terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.

TRENTON, June 1 Human error, equipment failure and design vulnerability were blamed today for an accident last Labor Day Weekend that knocked out the Trenton water-filtration plant on the Delaware River.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 1 John O. Parsons and Aldo Butera of the Ridgewood (Conn.) Country Club defeated Greg Zorilla ad Jack Dalrymple of the Siwanoy C.C. of Bronxville today in the one-hole continuation of sudden death for the Wilson Memorial Cup at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 1 (AP) Two time bombs exploded here today in the headquarters of the United States Army's V Corps, injuring 15 Americans and a German civilian, two of them seriously, an Army spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) One of the nation's largest oil-drilling tax shelters allegedly defrauded more than 2,000 wealthy investors by offering them $80 million in false income tax deductions, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 F. David Mathews, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was told today by the General Accounting Office that the Federal Treasury would no longer pay states for certain Medicaid programs whose standards on long-term hospitalization had not been enforced.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Federal Bureau of Investigation took steps in the mid-1960's to prevent the authors of a book about Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the convicted atomic spies, from discussing their work on television interview programs, according to newly released bureau documents.

The state of Pennsylvania and various agencies will provide nearly $100 million in loans and grants to help Volkswagen begin operations at the New Stanton assembly plant. Gov. Milton J. Shapp announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 Syrian tanks advanced deep into Lebanon along the Damascus-Beirut highway today and swung north to relieve Christian forces that have been surrounded by Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Moslems for several months.

Out of his five years in German concentration camps, the Polish theater man Jozef Szaina has composed a series of choreographed vignettes that he has entitled "Replika" and which was presented last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Slavic Cultural Center.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 1 (AP) The Minnesota Twins sent Bert Blyleven, the pitcher, to the Texas Rangers tonight in a six-player trade.

The move by City University mandated last night by the Board of Higher Education from free tuition to relatively high tuition among the nation's public universities is symptomatic of more than a local social and political trauma.

Managers of the Democratic National Convention took official control of Madison Square Garden yesterday, and New York City convention hosts gave the man who brought the smoke-puffing cigarette sign and other such spectaculars to Times Square the task of draping midtown in red, white and blue.

A Federal grand jury in Newark has indicted Villager Industries Inc., an apparel manufacturing subsidiary of Jonathan Logan Inc., two of Logan's officers and a partner in Clarence Rainess Company, a major New York accounting firm, on charges that they engaged in a conspiracy to file a fraudulent Federal income tax return.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) The British pound today sank to $1.17543, a new low, while the Swiss franc continued a strong advance and the dollar had a mixed showing on European currency markets.

TURIN, Italy, May 31 For 29 years, Armando Garabello worked in the factory of the Emanuel Company here, making automobile washing equipment. Two years ago the company went bankrupt and tried to close down, but Mr. Garabello and his fellow workers refused to let their jobs disappear.

ALBANY, June 1 Governor Carey today vetoed a bill widely viewed as an antibusing measure that would have subjected most decisions of the state's Commissioner of Education to direct review by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.
"Old Blue Eyes," Frank Sinatra, came to New York City last night to raise at least 500,000 greenbacks to help Governor Carey out of the red.
TOKYO, June 1 (AP) The Tokyo police department filed new charges against Yoshio Kodama today, accusing him of failing to report the receipt of $460,000 from the Lockheed Aircraft Corp.
After opening lower than Friday's close, prices for wheat, soybeans and soybean meal rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
JERUSALEM, June 1 (UPI) Archeologists have uncovered a section of a 1,860-year-old road in East Jerusalem in what was termed the most important archeological find from the Roman period in Jerusalem."

The Internal Revenue Service is conducting an investigation of the tax-exempt status of the Rev. Sun Myong Moon's Unification Church and other Moonaffiliated organizations, according to Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 1 A brawl with apparent racial overtones as classes were starting this morning at Central High School here resulted in injuries to eight white students and the arrest of three blacks, including two students who were suspended.
PATERSON, N.J., June 1 (AP) A 29-year-old Clifton woman who had a kidney transplant when she was 13 years old gave birth to a boy today in a birth her doctors called rare and "potentially dangerous."
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 1 Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin arrived here from Iraq today on a mission apparently intended to shore up the Soviet Union's uncertain position in the Middle East.
The Rev. Sun Myung Moon attracted 25,000 spectators to Yankee Stadium last night for a rally that his followers had predicted would fill the 54,000seat amphitheater to overflowing.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., June 1 (UPI) Two Wantagh, L.I., motorcyclists were killed and three of their companions seriously injured last night in a collision with two cars here, the Nassau County police reported.

WASHINGTON, June 1 President Ford telephoned gleeful supporters in Rhode Island tonight to tell them his sweep of the state's 19 convention delegates "will look awfully good in that win column" at the Republican National convention.

VIENNA Soviet diplomacy, skillful, patient and relentless, achieved a political settlement of World war II by signature of the Helsinki agreement on European security. That accord, accepted by the United States and all of Europe (save Albania), legally ratified existing frontiers on this continent.

GENEVA, June 1 (AP) About 15 Iranian students occupied the Iranian Consulate General in Geneva today for about two hours to protest what they said was a new wave of repression of political dissidents in Iran.
An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested in the fatal beating of a 22-year-old follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

WASHINGTON, June 1 President Ford and leaders of six other nations will discuss "the possibility of renewed inflation" at an economic conference late this month in Puerto Rico, the White House said today.

Officials of the New York Mercantile Exchange, center of the Maine potato futures debacle last week, convened after trading hours yesterday to set penalties against J.R. Simplot, the "Idaho potato king"; P.J. Taggares, another big factor in the industry, and their associates for defaulting on the delivery of 50 million pounds of potatoes.

Yaffa Simon, daughter of Rabbi E. Yechiel Simon, spirirual leader of the Clearview Jewish Center in Whitestone, Queens, and Mrs. Simon of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday evening to Rabbi Martin Katz, a teacher at the Ramaz Academy. He is the son of David Katz of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Katz.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) Seven independent oil companies were indicted today on Federal charges of illegally fixing the price of gasoline they sell in Middle Atlantic states.
Almost 15 percent of the National Hockey League players became free agents yesterday.
TEL AVIV, June 1 (AP) An Iraqi-born Jewish family has returned to Baghdad after 25 years in Israel, a newspaper here reported today.

Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California spent a busy day in New York City yesterday seeking support for a beyondthe-first ballot Presidential nomination at the Democratic National Convention here in July.
TRENTON, June 1 State prison officials said today they had canceled the work-release programs of 11 prison inmates who had been allowed to work outside prisons as part of a rehabilitation program.
A man was found yesterday lying on a sidewalk in Elmhurst, Queens, with a bullet wound in his abdomen and with one of his fingers cut off.

BOSTON The telephone in Larry Bondy's car rang as he drove to lunch here recently. Daniel Y. Greiff picked it up, had his East Boston office route in a call from a customer and took a $50,000 order for 300,000 pounds of steel.
PARIS, June 1 (Reuters) A French journalist says he accompanied a group of antiCommunist guerrillas in Cambodia earlier this month and found growing armed resistance to Cambodia's Government.

Noonday crowds on Fifth Avenue ogled the black Rolls-Royce with the British plates at the curb just south of 59th Street and a few passersby recognized the man mounted on a bicycle alongside the car. One who did, a black man with a tufted chin, reached across the hood to shake the cyclist's hand. Then Joe Frazier pedaled south through the traffic with a news photographer panting ahead, shooting pictures as he ran.

WASHINGTON, May 31 Senator Claiborne Pell is trying to end the term of Dr. Ronald Berman as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. The Senator is chairman of the two-man subcommittee that oversees arts and humanities matters.
It was Jack Nicklaus's intention to build a golf course where the world's best players "have to work hard to score." He succeeded when he built the Muirfield Village.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Robert F. Kelley, former head of the State Department's East European division and a founding officer of Radio Liberty, died here last night at George Washington Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates battled to a standoff in Tuesday's three primary elections, with five or six major candidates winning at least once as the voters continued to send conflicting messages about their preferences.
The primaries in Rhode Island, South Dakota and Montana produced indecisive results in both the Democratic and Republican Presidential contests.

At graduation ceremonies for the three branches of Hebrew Union College Jewish Institute of Religion this year, the Hebrew names of the graduates were printed on the program as usual. But in a departure from custom, most of the candidates listed themselves as the offspring of both mother and father, instead of the conventional reference to father alone.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 2 (Reuters) The Greek Cypriots have formally rejected Turkish Cypriot proposals made a week ago for talks on drawing a boundary between the two sides.
TRENTON, JUNE 2 Six candidates in the Democratic and Republican primaries next Tuesday stepped up their drives today for the United States Senate nominations.

Although beaten in the National Collegiate final, Peter Fleming has given Eastern tennis a shot of prestige. He came close to duplicating the feat of two other Easterners, Dick Stockton and Sandy Mayer, who won the N.C.A.A. title and then became professionals.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 2 (AP) The Boston Globe reported today that it had received a call from a man claiming responsibility for an explosion, last night at Plymouth Rock.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market finished with minor price changes yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

YONKERS If there is a break in the fiscal clouds over Yonkers, a city that lives with default deadlines, a likely place to look is Longfellow Middle School, where a student toy factory has had no problem meeting its payroll.
Not very much of anything happened at Herbert H. Lehman College yesterday.

A revised architectural design for the $65 million Palace Hotel planned for construction behind the landmark Villard Houses on Madison Avenue has been submitted to the City Planning Commission, which has tailored new zoning legislation to permit the project to proceed.

The city officially announced plans yesterday to lay off 3,150 workers at municipal hospitals by the end of the month because of the continuing fiscal crisis. The workers, who hold nonmedical jobs, responded by threatening a citywide munici pal hospital strike next Monday.
Arnold I. Goldberg, a lawyer, died Tuesday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 455 East 57th Street.
Dr. Quan Yung Kau, an abdominal surgeon, who practiced in Chinatown for more than 40 years, died Monday at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 The 55th annual National Collegiate track and field championships have attracted 1,573 athletes from 154 colleges, and some of them are the best in the world.

For the international bridge world, "Stayman" means a convention that nowadays has more varieties than Heinz. But in New York there are two other possibilities. It might also mean the convention's author, Sam Stayman, who is having one of his most successful New York seasons in his long career. And it might mean his wife, Tubby, a fine player in her own right who came close to winning the world mixed-team title two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) Francis Marziani, a former inmate at Lewisburg Federal prison who said he feared for his life because of evidence on inmate violence he gave to guards, was set free yesterday.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation warned yesterday that there could be serious problems with New York City's tight cash-flow plan requiring "corrective action of a significant nature" by next winter.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 2 The Giants bill it Orientation Week, a pre-training camp. But today, in the little valley they use as a football practice field, it looked and sounded like fulldress rehearsals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 A year after the end of hostilities in Vietnam, a visiting United Nations aid mission has found the Vietnamese striving to deal with the postwar dislocation of 8 million people, abandoned farm lands and a road and rail system all but disrupted.

Columbia University's 11year-old school of the arts will have Schuyler G. Chapin, former Metropolitan Opera general manager, 1972-75, as its dean beginning July 1. He will succeed Bernard Beckerman, age 54, who will continue as chairman of theater arts for the school. It has 800 undergraduate and graduate students and a faculty of 43.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his personal and political friends was rescheduled today to open Sept. 8 in Federal District court in Baltimore, three months later than planned.

LA CORUNA, Spain, May 27 Even the remote and underdeveloped region of Galicia, in Spain's northwestern corner, has been touched by the flowering of illegal but open political life in this country since the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Joe Torre remembers his embarrassment last season when strangers, out of politeness or ignorance, told him what a good job he was doing for the New York Mets. "I couldn't," he recalls, "even say thank you."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 28 More than 18 months after a group of radical soldiers deposed Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia is in the grip of a political and social upheaval that has left it sliding into economic disarray, armed repression and a mood of disillusion and fear.

MOSCOW, June 2 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today denied changes by Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia that it had interfered in Angola and was engaged in a worldwide political offensive backed by force and propaganda.
ALBANY, June 2 Chances for sweeping changes in the state's law governing financial settlements in divorce cases are dead in the Legislature for this year.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Hero," his 17th opera, is believed by its sponsors to be the first opera ever commissioned in Philadelphia. It was commissioned in 1974 by Lyric Opera of Philadelphia, a group that has since been merged into the Opera Company of Philadelphia, which presented the premiere.

Nelson Bunker Hunt, recently active as the nation's largest silver speculator, announced yesterday that Great western United, the sugar refiner of which he is chairman, would pay Panama in silver for raw sugar from June through December.
The New York Telephone Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for a $46.9 million rate increase to cover the cost of a 1976 wage increase for its employees.

Central bank intervention in the European currency markets "swelled to massive proportions" earlier this year amid widespread fears of major readjustments in currency values, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates battled to a standoff in Tuesday's three primary elections, with five or six major candidates winning at least once as the voters continued to send conflicting messages about their preferences.

ALBANY, June 2 In an attempt to alleviate the bleakness of life in some single-roomoccupancy hotels and remove the cloak of secrecy that often protects those responsible for the conditions, the Assembly passed a bill today to require licensing of the estimated 1,000 such structures in the city.
GENEVA, June 2 The United States and the Soviet Union resumed today their attempt to, reach agreements expanding their 1972 accords that curb their arsenals of strategic nuclear weapons.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 2 Ronald Reagan said today that Federal intervention in the classroom was responsible for much of the nation's educational deficiencies and he promised that if elected, President, he would issue instructions to Federal departments "to get off the back" of local school boards.

Maurice E. Nadjari has told friends and associates that he will refuse to stay on as special prosecutor if Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, agrees to any request by the Governor to appoint a second prosecutor with full powers to handle new corruption cases as of July 1.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 2 Two hundred left-wing priests and nuns shook the conservative Roman Catholic hierarchy of Colombia today with a public attack on the primate, Anibal Cardinal Munoz Duque, as "an accomplice of the system of injustice."
The collapse of the New York Mets grew worse last night when they were defeated by the Chicago Cubs, 5-3, for the 10th loss in their last 12 games and the 17th in their last 23.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (Reuters) Adm. Hyman Rickover, the man credited with introducing the nuclear submarine, was accused of insubordination by the Navy's civilian chief of contracts.

WASHINGTON, June 2 President Ford, acting on the assumption that Ronald Reagan will win the California primary next Tuesday, is preparing a major effort to obtain the support of uncommitted delegates to the Republican National Convention.
A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn has awarded a 6year-old girl $1.25 million for the loss of a leg as a result of medical malpractice by Brookdale Hospital and two physicians.
For those now in the market for a used automobile some call it a "jungle" there are many criteria to weigh before making a selection.

GENEVA, June 2 The annual conference of the International Labor Organization opened today in an atmosphere of such political bitterness that a newly elected chairman, Labor Minister Michael O'Leary of Ireland, warned that he might be presiding over "the breakup of the organization."
WHITE PLAINS, June 2 The Westchester County clerk, George Morrow, said today that he would continue to campaign for re-election despite two threats against his life.
A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn has awarded a 6year-old girl $1.25 million for the loss of a leg as a result of medical malpractice by Brookdale Hospital and two physicians.

WASHINGTON, June 2(AP) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that a group of Arab investors had agreed to back up a proposed assistance plan for De-, troit's troubled Bank of the Commonwealth.

Louis Ruchmaes, a professor of history at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, died yesterday at the New England Deaconness hospital. He was 59 years old. Professor Ruchames was born in New York City and graduated from City College, Columbia University and the Jewish Institute of Religion in New York.
Max Warmbrand, who advocated fruits, vegetables, sun and exercise in his books and lectures on nutrition, died yesterday at his Stamford, Conn. home. He was 80 years old.

William H. Haynes, vice president and a director of Arnold Clark Inc. of New Haven and Frankfurt, West Germany, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 47 Riverside Drive, Branford, Conn. His age was 50.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., May 28 The first thing to understand about the Maine potatoes futures crisis on the New York Mercantile Exchange, according to the average person here, is that it does not have much to do with the price of real potatoes. Farmers and potato processors think otherwise.

DEVON, Pa., June 2 Wile E. Coyote, who started out his career as a mediocre field hunter but found more successful pursuits in later life, won the amateur-owner jumper championship today at the Devon Horse Show.

The Rules, Privileges and Elections Committee of the New York City Council met briefly yesterday to consider 16 rule changes, but adjourned without acting after it could not get a quorum. Seven members of the 14-member committee gathered at 250 Broadway at 10 A.M., ready to act on the rule changes.

Mordecai Shehori, an Israeli pianist who made his debut here in 1974 after studying at the Juilliard School, gave a second recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night under the sponsorship of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation.

When Dow Chemical's stock sank 10 points within two trading days last week, it terrified some portfolio managers in bank trust departments. Dow, after all, is the favorite chemical of these particular money managers, who hold 20 percent of the company's common stock.
Editorial employees last night struck Time magazine and its sister publications Sports Illustrated, People, Money and Fortune magazines and the Time-Life book division.

Two of Randall Thompson's works, "Alleluia" and "The Testament of Freedom," are so popular that his other choral music is often neglected. So it was good to hear his "The peaceable kingdom" Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall.
LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP) The New York woman run ning for President on the antiabortion issue contends that other candidates insult th evoters' inelligence by making repeated visits to states.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 2 (AP) Employing a word dropped by President Ford from his Administration's vocabulary, Vice President Rockefeller said today that this country needed detente with the Soviet Union to develop a "better working relationship between the superpowers."

LYONS, France, June 1 A medical detective story of great potential importance in the fight against cancer is slowly unfolding, but while a mass of clues have been assembled, the final chapter remains to be written.

PHOENIX, June 2 The Phoenix Suns won both a foul-shooting contest and a basketball game against the Boston Celtics tonight to even their National Basketball Association championship series at two games apiece.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Manufacturers' inventories were essentially unchanged in April after a sizable increase in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

NEWARK, June 2 Nelson G. Gross, former Republican state chairman, surrendered to Federal authorities today to begin a two-year prison term on a conviction of managing an illegal campaign fund-raising scheme.
What do you do if a mugger strikes?

BOISE, Idaho, June 2 Jack Richard Simplot, the man everyone in Idaho calls the Potato King, admitted here today that he saw nothing unethical or illegal with the default by himself and some friends last week on the delivery of nearly 50 million pounds of Maine potatoes.
Maurice E. Peloubet, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse company, and resident of Cape May, N.J., died Tuesday at the age of 84. He was visiting Milwaukee at the time.

The attending physicians for Karen Anne Quinlan and officials of St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J., broke their silence yesterday to say that "prevailing medical practice and moral constraints" would continue to dictate the level of care being given to the comatose woman.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been looking into the apparent forgery within the Federal Energy Administration of a document that purports to urge stronger advocacy to the public of deregulation of natural gas prices.
Virginia Stewart, a retired teacher and bookshop owner, died yesterday of cancer at her home in Washington Depot, Conn. She was 71 years old.

With six weeks to go before the Democratic National Convention in Madison Square Garden, reality has turned into actuality for Patrick J. Cunningham of the Bronx. By taking a "leave of absence" as New York State Democratic Party chairman, he has effectively removed himself as a major power at the convention and, at the same time, been removed as a symbolic albatross around the Empire State's delegation.
City Hall began negotiations with its largest employee union yesterday and demanded more work for less pay, while the union asked for higher wages and cost-of-living increases.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 President Ford has drastically changed his campaign's approach to television advertising, replacing commercials that portrayed him as a thoughtful and effective President with a new series of TV spots that employ the techniques used to sell toothpaste and floor wax.

A criminal indictment against 11 major building maintenance concerns and 10 executives accused of conspiring to fix prices and avoid competition in New York City was dismissed in Federal Court yesterday by Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt on the ground that the indictment "shows nothing about any effect on interstate commerce."

What this country needs as the Bicentennial sappiness rises is a good Swiftian kick in its red, white and blue pants. Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Hero," a comic opera that had its world premiere at Philadelphia's Academy of Music on Tuesday night, doesn't deliver it. Mr. Menotti, who wrote the music and the libretto and also staged the production, is simply not a serious enough man for this kind of comedy.
ALBANY, June 2 Mayor Beame today rejected a call by Governor Carey for the city to increase its planned support for the City University in 1977.
The Celanese Chemical Company announced yesterday price increases on several organic chemical products, effective July 1.

Although women have been most prominent in performances of the Kurt Weill-Bertolt Brecht repertory and Martha Schlamme has been one of the most successful, Miss Schlamme's current partner at Reno Sweeney, Alvin Epstein, is striking a solid blow for male interpretations of these songs.
PARIS, June 2 The Syrian Foreign Minister, Abdel Halim Khaddam, arrived in Paris today to discuss the situation in Lebanon with French officials.
WASHINGTON, June 2 The House of Representatives approved a new foreign-aid bill today and refused by a decisive vote to put limits on American assistance to South Korea for its repressive policies.

WASHINGTON, June 2 In a rare decision, a Federal judge has disqualified a Washington law firm from handling an $800,000 claim against the Government because one of the firm's partners formerly was involved in the case as a lawyer for the Government.
Benjamin Franklin Howell Sr., who retired in 1959 as professor of paleontology at Princeton University, died last Friday in the Centre Community Hospital, State College, Pa. He was 85 years old.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 2 A cadet found guilty of cheating on a senior examination at the Coast Guard Academy here resigned before today's graduation, according to Academy officials.

Encouraged by Mayor Beame, three of New York City's major Democratic leaders are preparing to support Paul O'Dwyer, the City Council President, for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate a move that has contributed to "second thoughts" by Daniel P. Moynihan on his own prospective candidacy.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 Syrian troops who moved into eastern Lebanon yesterday stayed today in the positions they had reached.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Representative Thomas P. O'Neill, majority leader of the House, demanded today that Representative Wayne L. Hays give up his key committee chairmanships temporarily, pending the outcome of Federal investigations of his activities.
ALBANY, June 2 Chances for sweeping changes in the state's law governing financial settlements in divorce cases are dead in the Legislature for this year.

Ben Oglivie, a pinch-hitter, and Willie Horton, the designated hitter, supplied the batting power that carried the Detroit Tigers to their fourth straight victory, a 6-4 decision ever Milwaukee in Tiger Stadium last night.

After hovering at or falling behind the inflation rate in the earlier months of 1976, New York City retail sales in May plummeted 7.6 percent below the year-earlier level. It was the biggest monthly decline in more than a decade.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UPI) The White House today referred Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, who has requested 15,000 Federal troops to keep order in the city July 4, to his own state department if he thought he needed security assistance.

ALBANY, June 2 Faced with a policy shift in Washington, Governor Carey's office has had to come up with a new proposal to rescue the state's Housing Finance Agency, but Republicans in the Legislature are balking at certain aspects of it.

WASHINGTON This city is tired, worn out in a way that is peculiar to its unique life cycle. For 1976 is Year Eight the Year of the Lame Duck. We have so far been spared the doctoral theses and learned monographs on this phenomenon, but it exists, just like the stages of human growth.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Jacob Sheinkman, the general secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, outlined today the broad range of proposals that the union planned to make this summer in negotiations involving 100,000 workers in the cotton garment field.

The Amazing Rhythm Aces, a curiously named sextet from Memphis that made its first New York appearances Tuesday night and last night at the Other End, is one of the increasing number of Southern rock bands that are trying to make a virtue of stylistic diversity. Sometimes such eclecticism works to rob a band of personality and its live sets of focus. For the Amazing Rhythm Aces, it all fits together.
Braulio Baeza, out of action for 14 racing day's, apparently has lost no momentum as a result of his selfimposed exile.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it would make a new grant of $1 million to the Public Broadcasting Service to be used exclusively for the production of news documentaries and public-affairs programs next season.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 28 More than 18 months after a group of radical soldiers deposed Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia is in the grip of a political and social upheaval that has left it sliding into economic disarray, armed repression and a mood of disillusion and fear.

The advance in fixed-income security prices that got under way last Friday continued yesterday even though it paused briefly when the Federal Reserve temporarily drained some money from the banking system.
The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said in Houston yesterday that 2.8 million shares were tendered in response to its offer of May 7 to purchase all shares of the Empire Energy Corporation ...
LONDON, June 2 The British pound tumbled to $1.72 here today in one of the sharpest one-day declines in a yearlong descent, and a worried Government seemed powerless to do anything about it.

CHICAGO, June 2, (UPI) A Circuit Court jury reversed yesterday a medical malpractice suit, declaring the original plaintiff, her husband and her lawyers guilty of willful and wanton misconduct and awarding the defendant doctor $8,000 in damages.

TETERBORO, N.J., June 2 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California toured New Jersey today in a final, cooperative effort to stop former Governor Jimmy Carter of Georgia in next Tuesday's Democratic primary.

PARIS, June 2 The French Chief of Staff has given official blessing to French participation on NATO's front line in case of war. The development was the latest in a growing change of defense strategy involving all political groups here.
The stock market erased opening losses yesterday and closed moderately higher in continued slow trading.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 2 A band of top New York executives accustomed to commuting in comfort and still not resigned to the loss of their private parlor car abandoned the railroad entirely this morning and sought solace on a specially outfitted bus.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 2 Sixty years ago a group of avid golfers engaged a young golf architect from England, A.W. Tillinghast, to build a course for them in the woods of Westchester County. Tillinghast proceeded to create what is considered one of the finest courses in the worlld for the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, said yesterday that he did not expect the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices until the end of this year. But from then on, it will increase them in pace with inflationary trends, he predicted.
TEL AVIV, June 2 In a marked change of mood, Israeli leaders showed today they frankly relished some aspects of the Syrian military involvement in Lebanon.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 2 (AP) Senator Joseph M. Montoya won yesterday the Democratic nomination for a third six-year term by a 2-to-1 margin over Robert R. Sims. In November, he will face Harrison Schmitt, a former astronaut who easily won the Republican Senate primary.
Merrill Lynch Company, parent of the world's largest, brokerage firm, announced yesterday the first three in a series of top-level executive promotions planned as part of a major expansion move.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) Britain told its 21 trawlers off Iceland today to resume fishing under an agreement that ended a seven-month dispute over fishing rights in Icelandic waters.

The city officially announced plans yesterday to lay off 3,150 workers at municipal hospitals by the end of the month because of the continuing fiscal crisis. The workers, who held nonmedical jobs, responded by threatening a citywide municipal hospital strike next Monday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 2 (UPI) Former President Juan Jose Torres Gonzales of Bolivia disappeared after leaving his house yesterday and sources close to his family said they feared he had been kidnapped. Mr. Torres, who has been living in Argentina as a political refugee, was reported missing last night.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 2 (AP) Don Bolles, 42 years old, an investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic, was critically injured today when a bomb exploded in his car, the police said.

MRAIJET, Lebanon, June 2 Just down the slope of the Beirut-Damascus highway, two T54 tanks of the Syrian Army are parked with their barrels pointed toward Beirut. A band of irregulars, followers of Kamal Jumblat, the Lebanese leftist leader, vow to fight them if they move any closer.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 Syrian troops who moved into eastern Lebanon yesterday stayed today in the positions they had reached.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., June 2 Steve O'Connell of Millburn set a one-mile record of 4 minutes 10.6 seconds at the New Jersey all-group interscholastic track and field championships tonight at Rutgers Stadium.

NEWARK, June 2 (AP) The Board of Public Utility Commissioners gave permission yesterday for two New Jersey companies to resume selling natural gas to new customers. The agency also established a priority list for gas users.

New York is a city frequently accused of callousness toward its past. Go away for a few days and when you come back it sometimes seems a building, store or restaurant long accepted as an unofficial neighborhood landmark has vanished, years before its time.

Like a number of other cultural institutions, the Whitney Museum of American Art is discovering television, or at least video. Through this Sunday, the museum's New American Filmmakers Series is featuring an 81-minute program of black-and-white videotapes made by William Wegman and John Baldessari. They are being shown daily at 12, 2 and 4 P.M.
WASHINGTON, June 2 The International Monetary Fund auctioned 780,000 ounces of its gold today at a price of $126 an ounce.
OTTAWA, June 2 The Canadian Government today announced a broad attack on unemployment, including measures to reduce abuses of the unemployment compensation system and to create incentives to work.

MIAMI, June 2 (AP) A man convicted of Intimidating Ronald Reagan with a toy gun and threatening the lives of Mr. Reagan, President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller was sentenced today to an indeterminate prison term.

BOSTON, June 2 At his ranch after he left the Presidency, Lyndon Johnson would meet with four or five field hands early in the morning. His voice was as urgent as it had been with the White House staff, but this was the sort of thing he had to say.

LEXINGTON, Mass. How should America's youth be educated? Almost everywhere there is conflict: Conservative parents and school boards ban books, fight for a return to "the basics," and argue about the value of innovation. In most school districts there is renewed concern about costs.

The District of Columbia's Department of Insurance has asked 16 major insurers in the fire and casualty business to consider supporting a financial reorganization program for the troubled Government Employees Insurance Company and advise it by June 22 of their decisions.

The tragic case of Karen Anne Quinlan continues to make medical and legal history. But the ordeal of Miss Quinlan's family continues, and so do the terrible questions raised by her case.
ALBANY (AP) Fifty-four of the 174 local school district budgets up for voter approval in May were rejected, the State Education Department has announced.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 2 Army Secretary Martin R. Holfmann said today that he was considering a review of the honor system at West Point, but he indicated that any such survey would remain within the military establishment.

EPSOM, England, June 2 Lester Piggott, riding down the plush lawn of Epsom's stretch faster than Queen Elizabeth II had travelled by Rolls-Royce just two hours earlier, won the English Derby for a record seventh time today.

GLYNDEBOURNE, England, June 2 The Glyndebourne Festival, now 42 years old, started its season last night with a new production of Verdi's "Falstaff." The opera festival remains one of the relatively few oases of tradition in an England beset by difficulties on every side.

In a trading session marked by large amounts of profit taking after a period of rising prices, corn futures turned in an unusual performance yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Tommy Davis, fast approaching the major league record for number of teams played on, signed a contract yesterday to play with the California Angels, his ninth club. Davis's total does not take into account his two stints with the Chicago Cubs, or his brief Stay with the New York Yankees this year.

The occasion was the $38,700 Youthful Stakes at Bel mont Park, an event that has provided a stepping stone to fame for such past winners as Man o'War, Chance Play, Battlefield, Native Dancer and Bold Ruler. Rock ledges are being torn out of the median, entrance lanes shifted a few feet, shoulders widened.

To the surprise of many floor traders, soybean and grain prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans for July delivery jumped more than 18 cents to close at $6.03 a bushel. Corn for July delivery ended at $3.06, up 9 cents.

Jacob S. Chalat, a lawyer in private practice here who specialized in civil and international law, died yesterday morning in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 84 years old.

Edward Villella resigned yesterday from the cast of "Pal Joey," the Rodgers and Hart musical in which he was to have attempted his first major Broadway role. Joe Morgan of the Cincinnati Reds leads all players in the first week of balloting for the National League All-Star team that will oppose the American League All-Stars in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium on Tuesday night, July 13, Morgan, the league's most valuable player last season, has received 54,133 votes in the balloting that will continue through July 4. His closest competitor for the starting second-base job is Dave Cash of Philadelphia, with 30,322 votes.

OTTAWA, June 10 (UPI) Minister of Energy Alastair Gillespie today announced increases in the export price of natural gas that will raise energy costs of United States consumers next year by $320 million.

ALBANY, June 10 The State Senate's Republican leadership, in a major political concession to its Democratic opponents, has accepted most of the City University rescue plan passed last night in the Assembly. Action on the compromise measure in Both houses is scheduled for tomorrow.

SEOUL, South Korea Quiet efforts by the United States to ease the authoritarian human and civil rights policies of the South Korean Government of President Park Chung Hee show no signs of having any effect, according to interviews with diplomats, South Koreans and other observers here.

The marriage of Anne Barbara Perlo to Michael A. Levine, a vice president of the Consumer Services Group of Citibank, took place at the Plaza Hotel last evening. Rabbi Ephraim Kolatch performed the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, resigned today as President Ford's floor manager for the Republican convention in Kansas City.

After shadowboxing in a limousine and sparring on the Avenue of the Americas. George Foreman stopped pulling punches at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, June 10 (AP) Armed men stole a list of names and addresses of thousands of political refugees living in Argentina, touching off fears that some might be murdered, officials said today.

TRENTON, June 10 There was no endorsement of Jimmy Carter today from the Democratic Party's uncommitted delegates who defeated him Tuesday. Instead, there was the prospect of a political collision between Governor Byrne and Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. that could embarrass the party and undermine efforts now under way to unite it behind Mr. Carter's prospective Presidential nomination.

Keith Berger and his oneman "Mime Over Matter" is on stage at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow, and where did Keith Bergen get his start? In front of the Public Library, on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in the vicinity of the Pulitzer Fountain, that's where: on the street. Who knows how many Keith Bergers are running around loose on a Saturday night?

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 The first units of a "symbolic" peacekeeping force that the Arab League has decided to send to Lebanon arrived today as quiet was reported from most of the fighting fronts around the country.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 10 A further cut in the price of heavy crude oil was announced today by Iran, the second largest producer among the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

In a speech that he has been giving since March to various members of his top management, Jeremiah J. Attridge, vice president and general manager of corporate advertising and sales promotion of the Johns-Manville Sales Corporation, has been pointing out that the organization gave up large-scale corporate advertising 20 years ago and dropped from 117th on the Fortune 500 list in 1956 to 221st in 1970.
Today through Sunday: Feast of St. Anthony of Padua. (Sullivan and West Houston Streets, Manhattan.) SP 7-2755.

DeKALB, Ill., June 10 DeKalb County, Ill., is corn and Republican country. This is the home of the barbedwire fence and hybrid corn two inventions that revolutionized American agriculture. It is not worrying too much about Presidential politics these days. Its mind, as usual, is on the land.

The nation's basic money supply climbed by $1 billion in the latest statement week and business loans at leading New York City banks declined by $269 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

THE case of Giorgio de Chirico is one of the strangest in the annals of modern art. So strange indeed that Mr. de Chirico, who will be 88 years old on July 10, looks at times more like a character in a far-fetched novel than a distinguished figure in the history of art.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The House ethics committee has requested that a dozen newsmen, including three reporters for The New York Times, voluntarily answer questions dealing with the unauthorized disclosure of the report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence.
ALBANY, June 10 Governor Carey today asked the legislature to require all local governments in the state to adhere to uniform standards of financial disclosure before issuing bonds or notes.

In a sensible compromise, the leadership of the State Senate has agreed to accept the first-year portion of the package to rescue City University proposed by Governor Carey and approved by the Assembly.
The Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer, and the Inland Steel Corporation, the sixth largest, yesterday joined other leading companies yesterday in raising prices.

J.P. Stevens Company, the Southern textile chain, said yesterday that it considered the threatened labor boycott of its products "an improper use of the combined power of many unions."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 10 (AP) Black nationalist guerrillas have entered Rhodesia from neighboring Zambia and opened a second front in their fight against the white minority Government here, a Government spokesman said today.

ALBANY, June 11 The Democratic-controlled Assembly today passed its own version of a bill altering the way in which medical malpractice cases are considered by courts, incorporating only one minor provision from a significantly different bill passed by the Republicancontrolled Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The Senate Finance Committee approved today the highly controversial Ford Administration plan to reduce the capital gains tax on property that has been owned for an extended period of time.

Experts have deplored the steady diet of gore and violence on television. Psychologists have denounced its effects. Civic groups have cajoled the programmers to play down the mayhem. Task forces have urged change. The impact of all these pleas has been minimal.

Soybean meal continued its price surge yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, closing up $2.50 at $203.50 a ton for July delivery. During the session it hit a contract high of $207.50.
The Allied Chemical Corporation disclosed yesterday that improper payments totaling $335,750 were made to a purchasing agent of one domestic customer in a four-year period.

It is difficuit to imagine anyone other than Edward Villella in the central role of Jerome Robbins's "Watermill." Perhaps because no one else has done it? More Likely it's because of Mr. Villella's incredible intensity, which makes the work move around him like a twisting cloud circling the still eye of a storm.
NEWARK, June 11 The general manager of Decamp Bus Lines said today that he had "great hopes" of reaching a settlement on Monday of the three-week strike by drivers and garage workers.

Several college presidents at the City University said yesterday they expected that the university could be reopened on Monday if the package to rescue it was passed by the Legislature last night, which it was.

The merger of the Shenandoah Oil Corporation of Fort Worth into E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company, first announced in February, moved a step closer to completion yesterday ...

Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday that he was prepared to open a grand jury investigation into allegations that New York City might have been defrauded by some concessionaires operating in city parks and public places.

Judith Rubin Friedberg of New York, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Rubin of Pittsfield, Mass., and Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday evening to David Mark Richman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richman of New York. Rabbi Charles G. Agin performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

PLAINS, Ga., June 11 (AP) Noting the growing stream of visitors to this southwest Georgia town that is the home of Jimmy Carter, 8-year-old Amy Carter, Mr. Carter's daughter, and some friends set up a stand Thursday and began selling lemonade at 5 cents a glass.

The first national meeting of nonprofit professional theater groups, sponsored by the Theater Communications Group, will get under way tomorrow evening at Yale University in New Haven. More than 200 leaders of 105 American theater groups from 66 cities will participate in the four-day working conference. The theater directors, managers and board members will be joined by foundation programs officers and theater-service organizations' directors.

Old bottles fascinate Susan Mayer, an art director with a pharmaceutical advertising agency. She couldn't resist a crate of 250 of the grimy old things, made in Paris by Durafort for Willamson Hogg, chemists in North Shields, England, and used over and over again from 1900 through World War II to dispense lemonade, orangeade and ginger beer to thirsty Britons.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 11 Inspectors at the grain elevator operated here by Cargill Inc., one of the two largest grain companies in the world, said that Cargill employees had instructed them to misgrade grain, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified today.

Hastings was a member of the State Legislature from 1963 to 1968, he and two colleagues shared a downtown Albany apartment for a time that was known as a "super pad," a rendezvous where parties began when the bars closed. On the snowy capital scene, it was a place of refuge for legislators, aides and secretaries.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 In a study to be published soon, a Philadelphia-based environmentalist coalition says Pennsylvania water users have no legal basis for their contention that northeastern New Jersey must stop taking water from the Delaware River.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, praised Congress yesterday for "acting constructively" in trying to limit total spending under the new Congressional budget control procedures.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market posted their second consecutive advance yesterday in continued sluggish trading.

To Lynn Seymour must go our thanks not only for her magnificent performance in "Giselle" Thursday night with American Ballet Theater, but also for reminding us that there are many performing traditions behind this celebrated ballet.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 11 Two young sisters who fled their interim foster home a week ago to dramatize their wish to be reunited with their original foster parents turned themselves in to the Nassau County police this morning.

LIVE GROOVE WKCR-FM, the student-run radio outlet at Columbia University, has a loyal army of listeners, including some well-known jazz exponents whose music is aired frequently, along with the station's library of classics. Mortimer L. Medrich, an investment broker, died Thursday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y., of cancer. He was 71 years old.

Horacio Vaggione and Elisabeth Wiener, electronic musicians from Argentina and France respectively, have been giving a series of concerts at 72 Wooster Street this month, in conjunction with a group of dancers choreographed primarily by Kevan Cleary; the remaining dates in the series are tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11 A spokesman for an Angolan nationalist movement that was defeated in the recent civil war said here today that his faction had rallied support and was scoring gains in a continuing guerrilla campaign.

A special meeting of shareholders of the Government Employees Insurance Company has been scheduled for July 23 in Washington, the company's chairman, John J. Byrne, announced yesterday. When cracks appear in concrete or masonry walls, walks or patios, it is always a good idea to patch them as soon as possible in order to keep the condition from getting worse. Open cracks allow moisture to enter, which can hasten the deterioration process still further. In addition, during the winter when temperatures drop below freezing, moisture inside these crevices will freeze and expand, opening the crack or joint still more.
