Appearing in her first "Concerto Barocco" anywhere, Ghislaine Thesmar has undoubtedly discovered that George Balanchine's choreography is her best friend on stage, though it never hurts to have Peter Martins there as well. Colleen Neary was the other principal Sunday afternoon at State Theater during a beautiful, lyric performance of the piece.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Supreme Court today declined to review a Federal Power Commission order setting a uniform ceiling price for sales of natural gas at the wellhead by producers.
Thomas A. McGuire, retired president of Local 15 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, died Sunday at his Bronx home. He was 71 years old.

When Philadelphia's Mike Schmidt hit 16 home runs in his team's first 55 games, and Dave Kingman wound up with 22 in the first 62 Met games, the possibility arose that either or both might challenge one of baseball's most neglected but truly noteworthy records the National League mark for homers in one season, set at 56 in 1930 by Hack Wilson of the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) A Justice Department study group said today that a number of actions, including the matching of birth and death certificates, are necessary to ease a nationwide identification crisis costing at least $20 billion a year.
The City University of New York reopened yesterday after a two-week shutdown as students, teachers and staff members returned to 20 campuses in an atmosphere of relief, confusion and anger.
Resigned rather than enthusiastic, New York's top Democrats, jumped aboard the Jimmy Carter Presidential bandwagon yesterday.

Representative Morris K. Udall, holding the second largest bloc of Democratic convention delegates, ended yesterday his active pursuit for more and conceded his party's Presidential nomination to Jimmy Carter.
In the 18th-floor cafeteria of the newly reopened City University Graduate Center on West 42d Street yesterday, there was chicken Tetrazzini in almost every pot.

New York City's concrete waste containers are going to the scrap heap, Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarel lo disclosed yesterday. He said they were more trouble that they were worth, and the Sanitation Department has begun quietly removing them from sidewalks.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 14 (AP) Nelma Joan Henderson was fatally injured today when a horse she was exercising at Churchill Downs struck the rail, throwing her to the track.
The Department of Justice is investigating a boycott of a trading-floor specialist on the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street sources disclosed last night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14 A garrison of the dissident group called the Lebanese Arab Army today was said to have fallen to Syrian troops in southeastern Lebanon while light fighting was reported from the mountains northeast of Beirut.

New York City's property tax base shrank this year for the first time in 33 years, and independent experts predicted yesterday that the tax rate would rise by nearly 8 percent, to $8.836 per $100 of assessed valuation.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) City transit workers have approved a plan to shut down all trolley, subway and bus service in Philadelphia on July 4.

SYDNEY, Australia June 14 Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser began a series of overseas visits this week that were interpreted here as an attempt by the Australian leader to counter what he sees as a growing Soviet threat, by developing closer ties with Japan, China and the United States.

New York City's property tax base shrank this year for the first time in 33 years, and independent experts predicted yesterday that the tax rate would rise by nearly 8 percent, to $8,836 per $100 of assessed valuation.

A Federal fact-finding panel, set up to try to avert a strike by 40,000 workers in New York City's voluntary hospitals, recommended yesterday, the negotiation of a cost-of-living increase and binding arbitration if the union and the hospitals reach an impasse.

LOUISVILLE, June 14 Several business leaders testified today that they were the victims of an intense campaign of intimidation and harassment, including boycotts and threats to bomb, burn and kill, during desegregation of schools here last fall.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 14 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters went on the offensive today, defending the union, flaunting its success and opening a stinging attack on union dissidents.
Following are updated plans released by the City University for the completion of the spring semester:
If a panel of designers or anti-designers, as the case may be took it upon themselves to create the most uncomfortable, inconvenient and unattractive vehicle pos sible, they would ...
Fixed-income security prices continued to rise yesterday, and the Federal Reserve reinforced the credit market's more optimistic atmosphere by purchasing Treasury bills for its own ...

Over 100,000 residents of the Far Rockaway area were assured of continued hospital care yesterday when Church Charity Foundation, an arm of the Episcopal church, agreed to take over the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hospital on July 1.

With the slow-moving United Nations Law of the Sea Conference adjourned until August, leaving critical issues of ocean law unresolved, the moves to stake out ever-wider national claims to jurisdiction at sea appear to be accelerating ominously.

WASHINGTON, June 14 President Ford's setback in Missouri will not prevent him from converting enough convention delegates to win the Republican Presidential nomination, White House political strategists said today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 14 (AP) Senator J. Glenn Beall, Republican of Maryland, said today that he made an "extremely poor decision" six years ago when he concealed information that the Nixon White House funneled $180,000 into his successful campaign against former Senator Joseph D. Tydings, a Democrat.

ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N.Y., June 14 Barring an unforeseeable chain of disasters, 16-year-old Keith Notary and his football player crewman, David Gamblin, appear to be headed for Olympic uniforms. The pair from Merritt Island, Fla., are sailing themselves and their Tornado catamaran onto the Olympic yachting team which will compete in Kingston, Ontario, next month.

WEST BERLIN, June 14 The press spokesman for West Berlin's governing Social Democratic Party and his former wife have been arrested on suspicion of spying for East Germany, the city prosecutor announced today.

Frank H. Canaday of Woodstock, Vt., a retired executive of the United States Advertising Corporation, Toledo, Ohio, and an art enthusiast who donated contemporary American paintings to museums in New Zealand, died Sunday in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital, Hanover, N.H., after a prolonged illness. His age was 83.

NYACK, N.Y., June 14 A convoy of 30 wagons and 50 riders on horseback crossed the Tappan Zee Bridge today and then began a 16-day tour of New Jersey on its way to a Fourth of July rendezvous at Valley Forge, Pa.

BRUSSELS, June 14 (Reuters) Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will fly to Africa tomorrow to discuss the security situation in eastern and central Africa with Government leaders in Kenya and Zaire, the United States delegation to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced today.

Over 100,000 residents of the Far Rockaway area were assured of continued hospital care yesterday when Church Charity Foundation, an arm of the Episcopal church, agreed to take over the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hospital on July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 14 President Ford, saying that bribes paid by United States corporations to foreign officials threatened "to harm our foreign relations," called today for legislation that would require the disclosure of all such "questionable payments."
KANSAS CITY, Mo. In anticipation of the Republican National Convention here in August, this city is trying hard to make its face resemble the famous smile button.
Although he lost $1.2 million in the first year's production of "Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman," Norman Lear, the producer said yesterday the syndicated comedy soap opera would be continued next fall.

The committee that has been working to put into effect City Charter revisions approved by the voters last November has drawn up tentative lines for coterminal service districts in four of the five city boroughs.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The Supreme Court refused without comment today to review the court-ordered plan for desegregating Boston's public schools a plan that requires substantial busing and that President Ford has repeatedly criticized.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 14 (UPI) Ethiopia's military Government has apparently decided to disband a peasant army that it had mobilized to fight a war against Eritrean rebels and thousands of peasants have already started to straggle home on foot, diplomatic sources said today.
Jennifer Lynch hesitated before stepping onto the tennis court and turned to her father. "But what if we lose?" she said softly.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 14 The top favorites, led by Marilyn Aschner, moved into the fourth round of the Eastern women's claycourt tennis championship at the Orienta Beach Club today. Miss Aschner won twice without the loss of a game.

Watergate demonstrated that unfettered executive discretion can lead to serious abuse of the constitutionally dubious practice of installing "national security" wiretaps without authorization from the courts.

CHICAGO, June 14 (Reuters) A 51-year-old mother of three was shot dead in front of her children, and 15 other people, including her husband, were injured here last night in racial violence that erupted in the aftermath of a tornado that killed two people southwest of the city.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 14 (UPI) Two Barques from the Soviet Union, Tovarishch and Kruzenshtern, were declared the unofficial winners today of the Tall Ships race from the Canary Island to Bermuda. Race officials declared the two vessels the winners after correcting the times of the 42 ships involved. Confirmation of the results was expected tomorrow.

Faced with opposition from some community school districts, Chancellor Irving Anker has shelved, at least for the present, a controversial plan to save $8.2 million a year by returning all fifth-grade and sixth-grade pupils who are now in intermediate and junior-high schools to elementary schools.

The New York Times will take on a new appearance next September by changing its format of eight columns on a page to one of six columns for news and nine columns for display advertisements, the newspaper's publisher. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, announced yesterday.

Henry Aaron, the major league's career home run leader, is not hitting home runs the way he once did, and his prowess finally may be winding down after 22 big league seasons. But Aaron showed some of the old spark in Milwaukee last night, hitting one of the three home runs that led the Brewers to an 8-2 victory over the California Angels.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 14 (AP) Rhodesia's white minority Government recommended several moves toward racial equality today, including the establishment of nonsegregated election rolls and nonsegregated ownership of commercial and agricultural land.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 14 (AP) The trial of Eldridge Cleaver, the former Black Panther leader, on charges stemming from a shootout with Oakland policemen in 1968 was postponed today while Mr. Cleaver seeks a new attorney.

Hostos Community College, the six-year-old bilingual institution that seemed a prime candidate for extinction because of the city's fiscal crisis, reopened yesterday along with the other schools in the City University system under a state rescue plan in which it was given a favored status.

Sunday night, Randy Newman, Dave Van Ronk and Warren Zevon all appeared in Manhattan, and Mr. Newman, crusty eccentric that he is, managed, all unawares, to cast the other two quite decisively into the shade.
Once a woman's gotten her name on the office door and, of course, a carpet on the floor won't she also want a good-looking briefcase, instead of shoving papers higgledy-piggledy into a tote bag?
PARIS, June 14 Prime Minister Jacques Chirac emerged strengthened today from a behind-the-scenes crisis that nearly shattered the French Government.

The Yankees beat the Mets, 8-4, at Yankee Stadium last night for their sixth Mayor's Trophy game victory in the last seven games and their eighth in 14 over all. More significant than this continued mastery over their borough rivals, per haps, was the return to action of two injured outfielders for the first time this season.

William J. Closs, an engineer who helped make Pratt Whitney a leader in the manufacture of aircraft engines, died Sunday while vacationing at Rangely, Me. He was 61 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

Nine individual holders of May potato futures contracts and an investing company have filed the latest in a series of lawsuits against the New York Mercantile Exchange, the traders who defaulted on contracts sold and their brokers.

TRENTON, June 14 Twenty Democratic Senators were reported to have agreed in caucus this afternoon to support a 1.5 percent state tax on personal income, and Senate President Matthew Feldman said a floor voted on the tax would come on Thursday.

A telephone solicitation campaign, in which Manhattan businessmen are being asked to buy advertisements in a publication called the National PAL Magazine, has drawn a strenuous objection from officials of the Police Athletic League in New York City.

Representative Morris K. Udall, holding the second largest bloc of Democratic convention delegates, ended yesterday his active pursuit for more and conceded his party's Presidential nomination to Jimmy Carter.

The top two finishers were disqualified in the ninth race at Belmont Park yesterday, which may have provided a windfall for "stoopers," those bettors who search the ground after a race looking for discarded winning tickets.
The Federal Court of Appeals overturned yesterday an order excluding the public and press from a trial of a $5 million negligence suit brought by Connie Francis Garzilli, the singer and entertainer.

Rains over growing areas usually dampen speculators' enthusiasm for buying corn and soybean contracts. Yesterday, however, prices for soybeans soared, and corn showed slight or no declines in various trading months despite heavy rains and more expected in key Middle West growing areas.

For a long while, Willie Montanez has been saying he would like to play baseball in a warm climate. The 28year-old native of Puerto Rico has spent four years of his major-league career in Philadelphia and one in San Francisco's windswept Candlestick Park.

Expressing "concern" at the pace of New York City's budget-cutting efforts, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon yesterday abruptly scheduled a meeting Thursday between his staff and the Emergency Financial Control Board to discuss "questions" involving the city's financial plan.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 14 (UPI) President Idi Amin of Uganda denied as "false and malicious" today reports that hundreds of people had been killed in a nationwide purge caused by an attempt to kill him.

The American oil industry has grown to world dominance under a structure in which the major companies control all their operations from production through marketing. But in recent months a question raised with growing intensity is whether the consumer is best served by such an arrangement.

California's voters have rejected by a resounding margin an ambitious public initiative to restrict the development of nuclear power in that state. Only the most enthusiastic industry lobbyists, however, could claim that the vote flashed a green light for untrammeled nuclear expansion. Quite the opposite message is being registered in state capitols across the country, where legislative measures are gaining support to enforce stringent requirements on the construction of new nuclear power facilities.

HYANNIS, Mass., June 14 While the National Basketball Association owners wrestled with several plans here today for a merger with the rival American Basketball Association, about 450 miles away in Buffalo, the Braves were sold and would be moved to Hollywood, Fla., if the sale is approved.

Victor Gotbaum, exective director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employees, charged yesterday that the Temporary Commission on City Finances had misrepresented labor and fringe benefit costs for New York City employees in a report earlier this month.
Irving S. Shapiro, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company, yesterday was elected chairman of the Business Roundtable, a study group of 160 top-ranking corporate executives.

The stumbler shows signs of running. Saying so could jinx things, but Milan Stitt's play, which took 11 discouraging years and lots of rewrites to reach Broadway, teeters on the edge of creeping success.

E.B. White, the American essayist who has lived secluded with his hens, his hayfields and his typewriter on a farm in Maine for close to 40 years, has persuaded the Xerox Corporation, in an exchange of letters, to abandon the underwriting of magazine articles.

LUANDA, Angola, June 14 A Vietnam War veteran on trial here as a mercenary antagonized the court today by saying he had come "to stop a Russian Communist takeover." Another won congratulations on testifying that he had come "for money, for adventure" but was sorry.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) J. Paul Getty, who died June 6 at the age of 83, named 12 women in his will. A number of them can recall romances or near-romance with the American oil billionaire.

New York City will ask the state's Emergency Financial Control Board for direct power to deal with so-called nonmayoral agencies such as the City University that disregard the spending restraints of the city's fiscal plan.
Cosmos Parcel Express's drab storefront on Second Avenue and Fourth Street was closed yesterday, not because of a holiday or too little business, but because of too much.
The credit markets declined slightly yesterday, moving toward lower prices and higher interest rates as traders became nervous about a rise in the Federal funds rate above 5 percent.

Consumers have problems with one out of every four of their purchases, but most of these problems go unreported to business or complaint agencies, according to a study that drew upon the experiences of 2,500 urban households.

TEL AVIV, June 15 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin warned today that Israel's security interests and the stability of the entire Middle East would be jeopardized if the civil war in Lebanon ended with Syrians or Palestinians in control of the country.
WASHINGTON, June 15 The Senate approved today the first legislation in 30 years calling for more public disclosure of lobbying activities in Congress.
PEKING, June 15 The Chinese Government officially announced today that Chairman Mao Tse-tung was no longer receiving visiting foreign leaders.

ALBANY, June 15 Legislative leaders have reached bipartisan agreement to seek approval next week of constitutional amendments achieving key aspects of the lawmakers' longdiscussed program of court reform.

HYDE PARK, N.Y. The empty rooms of the Bellefield mansion here adjacent to the home of Franklin Delano Roosevelt echo these days only to the occasional footsteps of National Park Service rangers and local visitors.

The police have arrested a 14-year-old boy for the fatal stabbing of an actor in Greenwich Village Friday night and are seeking additional witnesses, including 10 or more youths who were with the suspect when the man was stabbed.

Soybeans, after leading grain prices ahead for about seven sessions tumbled sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Slight weakness in corn and wheat prices on Monday might have hinted that the retreat in beans was coming.

MIAMI, June 15 Growing American exports of modern weapon systems and nonmilitary technology could be detrimental to the nation's defense and economy, Dr. Fred C. Ikl , director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmamemt Agency, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June, 15 Treasury Department officials said today that they had asked New York City to submit a revised financial plan and obtain new labor agreements as a condition for further Federal loans.
The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices on structurals and plates in line with the previously announced increases of other producers, effective July 16.

BETHESDA, Md., June 15 A senior engineer who recently resigned after working since 1972 in the planning stages for the world's first floating nuclear power plant testified today that the plant design was unsafe.

LUANDA, Angola, June 15 Angolan prosecution witnesses accused 13 British and American mercenaries today of murder, massacre, laying minefields, abuse of civilians, pillage and the destruction of property.
The economic summit conference, which is to be held the end of this month in Puerto Rico, is being called Rambouillet II by the clich manufacturers within the United States Government.

Jon Matlack hurled a strong six-hitter for his eighth victory against one defeat. Dave Kingman scored a run and batted in the winning one. John Milner saved the game with a tremendous running catch in left field.
UNIONDALE, L.I., June 15 Joe Frazier's boxing career ended with a left hook tonight.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15 Charles O. Finley, the maverick owner of the Oakland A's, stunned the baseball world tonight by selling three of his biggeststars Vida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million and Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers to the Boston Red Sox for $1 million each. No player ever has been sold for that much money in baseball history.
TRENTON, June 15 (AP) The State Bicentennial Commission reported Tuesday that 512 of the 567 municipalities in New Jersey have been designated as official "Bicentennial communities."

Capital is the lifeblood of corporations. Capital technically, money available for investment pays for land, factories, machinery and new jobs. It finances inventories, and it bridges the gap between bills due and payments not yet received.

JERUSALEM, June 15 "An Israeli intervention in Lebanon new." a senior Government analyst observed here, "would only benefit the P.L.O."

The Beacon Theater was caught up in a time warp Monday and Tuesday nights, for the first of five metropolitanarea performances in theatersized halls by the Grateful Dead (the remaining three are tomorrow through Saturday at the Capitol Theater in Passaic, N.J., long since hopelessly sold out).

GENEVA, June 15 The European Economic community has protested in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that the United States has violated this agency's fair trade rules in imposing quotas of imports of specialty steel products.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company disclosed yesterday that it had filed a $30 million suit against the defunct Franklin National Bank on charges that Franklin failed to disclose its precarious financial position when Manufacturers Hanover was lending it money in 1974.

LONDON, June 13 A.J. P. Taylor, the distinguished British historian, says that the economic crisis engulfing the nation is entwined with a deeper crisis gripping the Western world. He says that British links to Europe are a "nuisance," that he welcomes the prospect of Communists participating in an Italian government and that Britain should face the problem of Northern Ireland head on and withdraw its troops as quickly as possible.
WASHINGTON, June 15 One of the four manufacturers of the swine-flu type of influenza vaccine said today that it was losing its liability coverage for the vaccine.

WASHINGTON, June 15 Senators Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Henry L. Bellmon of Oklahoma, the chairman and ranking Republican, respectively, on the Senate Budget Committee, asked their colleagues today to join them in an effort to overturn major aspects of the 1,536-page tax bill that has been approved by the Senate Finance Committee.

It's all right to watch Channel 13 again; the auction is over. It may even, in fact, be necessary: WNET's "Theater in America" season ends tonight at 9 o'clock with a two-hour presentation of "The Eccentricities of a Nightingale" by Tennessee Williams. Although there are problems, they are nothing that some fine acting can't take care of, and fine acting is what we get.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (UPI) City commissioners have 15 days to determine if there are enough valid signatures to force a recall referendum in answer to a petition to recall Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, presented today.

MOSCOW, June 15 (UPI) Pyotr N. Tretyakov, one of the Soviet Union's leading archaeologists and historians, died in Leningrad on Saturday, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported today. He was 66 years old.

NORFOLK, Va., June 15 Invoking the names of Jesus, George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Billy Graham and Jimmy Carter, President Ford declared today that the country required greater "righteousness" of its citizens and "personal integrity" of its public servants.

BETHESDA, Md., June 15 A senior engineer who recently resigned after working since 1972 in the planning stages for the world's first floating nuclear power plant testified today that the plant design was unsafe.

What Beame officials call the "month of the horribles" reached its midway point yesterday with fresh budget warnings to the city from the state's chief monitor and private misgivings from city officials about coming to terms with both fiscal watchdogs and union negotiators.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The once-fashionable cigarette is now smoked by fewer than 40 percent of adult Americans, and smokers are feeling increasingly beleaguered, according to information from a major survey.

WASHINGTON, June 15 West Germany announced today that Secretary of State Henry A, Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa would meet next week in the countryside and not in Hamburg as originally planned because their talks were vital and they needed a "secluded place."

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 15 Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, on his way to Africa, stopped off in Athens today and strongly urged Greek officials to normalize their waverling links to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Princess Grace of Monaco will be elected a member of the board of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation at the next board meeting July 29, Dennis C. Stanfill, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday. She will be the company's first woman board member.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) A Federal judge today renewed a temporary restraining order against proposed new food stamp regulations that would cut more than one million families from the program.

A check for $1.862 million was delivered yesterday to New York City's Finance Administration by Merrill Lynch Company the country's largest stock brokerage concern, in settlement of disputed corporate taxes for the years 1972 through 1974.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 The Environmental Protection Agency is instituting a highly controversial policy under which hundreds of major water polluters will be given time extensions for compliance of as much as four years beyond the mid-1977 deadline set in the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972.

Robin Hood Dell West, a spacious $8 million outdoor amphitheater that will serve as the new summer home of the Philadelphia Orchestra, emerged from the egg on Monday night. Eugene Ormandy conducted the premiere concert in the eyecatching pavilion in West Fairmount Park, across the Schuylkill River from the old Robin Hood Dell music shell where the orchestra for the last 46 years has bridged the gap between spring and fall concert seasons.

Although the skies hung heavy and leaden over Central Park on Monday, the 11th annual Schaefer Music Festival got off to a cheerful if atypical start at the Wollman Skating Rink Theater before an audience of 4,500 that filled slightly more than half the seats.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 15 Secretary General Mahmoud Riad of the Arab League met today in the village of Kfour with President Suleiman Franjieh and other Lebanese Christian leaders in an effort to soften their opposition to the dispatch of an Arab peacekeeping force to Lebanon.

The seers of the Interpublic Group of Companies are predicting that 1976 will show the greatest percentage increase of advertising spending over the previous year for any year since the end of World War II.

The chancellor of the City University of New York said yesterday that he would pay faculty members for the two weeks the system was shut down, an action that could leave the university $15 million short of meeting its other obligations for the rest of the fiscal year.

PASADENA, Calif., June 15 (UPI) Viking 1, approaching the planet Mars, was slowed slightly today and put on a course that probably will permit an historic landing on the red planet on the 200th birthday of the United States.

Before there was a listed option market, the small investor rarely got involved in arbitrage, in which a profit is sought through price disparities in related securities. Commission expenses ordinarily precluded reasonable profits, and the game was thus left to Wall Street professionals.

Despite their highly vocal objections to being treated like sheep and dictated to by fashion designers, women are happiest when rules are strictest about what should be worn and what shouldn't, according to some observers.
For office tenants, one of the most exciting and expensive games in town is escalation.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15 Thurman Munson rapped four hits and drove in three runs tonight as the Yankees defeated the Minnesota Twins, 4-2. But the game was overshadowed by the Yankees' reaction to their acquisition of Vida Blue.
With an eight-run lead after two innings, it was no problem for Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies to beat the San Francisco Giants, 10-2, last night in Veterans Stadium.

Profit taking and the Senate Judiciary Committee's vote to send a bill to break up 18 large oil companies to the Senate floor weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The over-the-counter market was mixed.

TOKYO, Wednesday June 16 (Reuters) Three earthquakes jolted central Japan today, causing one casualty leaving minor damage and disrupting train services. The casualty was caused when a boulder hit a driver's car.
WASHINGTON, June 15 With the Democratic Party apparently united for the first time in years, its Platform Committee adopted a platform tonight that was extolled by all the factions of the party.

LAXENBURG, Austria Collaboration between practitioners from highly diverse professional and political backgrounds has developed a new analytical method applicable to such varied fields as pest control, weather prediction, ecology, chemistry and economics.
Dr. Marcel Heiman, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died of cancer Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 1148 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today, by an 8-to-7 vote, to send to the floor a bill to break up 18 large oil companies into-separate production, refining and refining-marketing entities.

A black-hooded undercover agent for the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor testified yesterday that port employees had easy access to a network of lawyers and doctors who helped them file and collect on fraudulent claims for workmen's compensation.

WASHINGTON, June 15 A toughly worded Civil Service Commission report last month, which acknowledged wrongdoing and complicity in preferential Government hiring practices during the Nixon years, was part of a commission plan to limit damage to its reputation and to ward off serious scrutiny from outside.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The House Veterans Affairs Committee voted today to increase monthly payments for 5.5 million veterans and dependents receiving pensions and disability payments to match cost-of-living increases.

Kalman H. Silvert, a program adviser for the Ford Foundation and an authority on Latin American affairs, died yesterday of a heart attack at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 55 years old and lived with his family in Greenwich Village.

Hurok Concerts Inc. announced yesterday that it had filed suit in State Supreme Court against Sheldon Gold, Hurok's former president, and against ICM Artists Ltd. and its parent company, Marvin Josephson Associates Inc.
Thousands of dead menhaden are being reported along the Hudson River between Manhattan and Dobbs Ferry in what is regarded as an annual phenomenon, probaly resulting from weather chances.

BAYANO BRIDGE, Panama In one of the world's wildest rain forests, a young American biologist and a group of Panamanian Indians are trying to rescue animals of all species from the rising waters of a new dam.

"I've got 110 Ellington LP's," Jack McDonough was saying on Sunday. "I think I've got every Ellington LP there is. I've got more than 600 Ellington 78's, but I never play them any more. I can't stand the poor fidelity."

The University of Cincinnati has lost its long struggle to retain its independence as a municipal institution and will become part of the Ohio state university network in July 1977.

ALBANY, June 15 (AP) Richard Rosenbaum, New York state's Republican Party chairman, expects 10 or 11 of the state's 16 remaining uncommitted Republican convention delegates to cast first-ballot votes for President Ford, a spokesman said today.

Last week this space was given over to the results of a blind tasting of California white wines and some topgrade white wines of Burgundy. The tasting was held in Paris, the tasters were all French and the American wines took first, third, fourth and sixth places when all the points were added up.
Letter bombs that are turning up in the mails throughout the country were described yesterday as follow-ups to extortion demands addressed to about 200 leading business executives since last fall.

Federal social-service officials have been making a study of New York City's day-care programs for the last two weeks, analyzing central administration, staffing ratios, controls and the much-criticized direct-leasing of centers.

ROBERTS ISLAND, Nova Scotia Young wild boars can be cooked exactly like fresh pork. "But one difference between a wild boar ranging the woods and a domesticated pig," Carlo Amato was saying as the plane circled Yarmouth Harbor, "is that a wild boar climbs higher and will step over obstacles in his path. A domesticated pig walks around them."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (Reuters) The Senate Judiciary Committee overwhelmingly approved today a proposal by President Ford requiring the Government to obtain court orders for virtually alt wiretaps for foreign intelligence and national security purposes in the United States.

Time flew back 30 years at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was the premiere of American Ballet Theater's new and sumptuous production of the Petina/ Tchaikovsky classic "The Sleeping Beauty." But in a very real sense it was a reproduction of the staging Britain's Royal Ballet first unveiled at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, in 1946, and the very same production that conquered New York three years later.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Clyde M. Webber, 56 years old, president of the 325,000member American Federation of Government Employees, died today of cancer.

The Metropolitan Opera presented "Aida" last night with the world's most spectacular set, the Manhattan skyline, as a backdrop. Colored balloons hung over the Central Park audience, a searchlight played across the skies in the finest Hollywood premiere style, and a flashing sign in the distance proclaimed that the temperature was a warm but not suffy 84 degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The great advantage of winning the Presidential nomination in the state primaries is that it gives Governor Carter an extra month to pick a running mate, define the central theme of his campaign and begin thinking about a Cabinet.
DETROIT, June 15 (AP) Domestic new car sales during the first 10 days of June registered a 41 percent increase based on the daily selling rate, the nation's automakers reported today.

New York City's major taxicab fleet operators are reporting "no interest at all" in those roomy, comfortable cabs of the future to be on display starting Friday at the Museum of Modern Art.

Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, said yesterday that he anticipated heavier markdowns in the retail industry during the current second quarter than in 1975 since "one-third of the quarter is already represented by lower sales than a year ago."

JERSEY CITY, June 15 (AP) A Hudson County bank, the former president of which admitted misusing bank funds, has been declared insolvent and its assets sold to another New Jersey bank.

Smith, who assumed the editorship of The San Francisco Chronicle in 1937 at the age of 26, then 15 years later vainly fought to save three Crowell-Collier magazines the American Collier's and Women's Home Companion died here today of a stroke. PARIS In 356 B.C., a man named Herostratos set fire to the most famous temple of the goddess Diana merely, as he confessed, to make himself famous. Even though the mention of his name was declared a capital offense, this criminal is still famous today. When the attention of contemporaries is drawn to a man totally unremarkable except for some unusually destructive act he has committed or threatened to commit, we speak of herostratism.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 18 Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham, who had triumphed in 1966 and 1974, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association match-play championship again today. In the 73d staging of the event, she defeated Mrs. Charles Crawford of Apawamis, 5 and 4, in the final at the Canoe Brook Country Club.
ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N.Y., June 18 In a new Olympic yachting class whose "heavyweights" must be lightweights, Skip Whyte and Neal Fowler are breaking all the dietary rules.

Pablo Casals died only four years ago, but at such an advanced age and still so active up to his very last days, it seems hard to believe that his centenary is being observed this year. The great cellist, conductor and humanitarian was so admired and loved that his anniversary is being celebrated in his native Spain, and in France, Switzerland, Mexico and Japan.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday in moderate trading.

Two leaders of independent taxi owner-driver associations have clashed with officials of the Museum of Modern Art over the museum's exhibit of prototype cabs of the future, and one leader said that he was ejected from the show.

With the count three and two, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has thrown a high hard one at baseball's moguls. Instead of allowing the ballfield to be turned into a bank vault, he has voided the multimillion-dollar deal that would have sent three Oakland A's stars to the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox. His reasoning that the transaction was contrary to "the best interests of baseball" seems to be right in the strike zone.

Don Lofgran, a former all America basketball star at the University of San Francisco and professional player, was found dead Thursday morning in a hotel room in Salt Lake City. The police there suspected alcoholic poisoning as the cause of death. He was believed to have been 46 years old.

LEON, Spain The technique of Spain's present Government after almost four decades of Generalissimo Franco's dictatorship bears some resemblance to the technique of Henry Kissinger's step-by-step diplomacy in the Middle East. In each case the ultimate goal is obvious: peace between Israel and the Arabs in the second instance; democracy and constitutional monarchy in the first.

Plutonium, when ingested, can be one of the most poisonous substances known to man. In metal form it is relatively safe to handle, but potentially far more lethal than poison. A stolen quantity the size of a grapefruit, shaped into a bomb by urban guerrillas or saboteurs, could destroy a city the size of Hiroshima.

The former law partner of a previously indicted judge was accused yesterday of participating in a liquor license bribery and conspiracy scheme, which accidently led to the controversial corruption investigation of Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader.

Alice Crimmins, the former cocktail waitress now serving five to 20 years in a halfway house for manslaughter in the death of her 4-year-old daughter, Alice Marie, filed papers in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday seeking a new chance to appeal her conviction.

WASHINGTON, June 18 The growth in the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, is likely to slow substantially in the current quarter to considerably less than 5 percent on an annual basis, Government economists said today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that its director, Clarence M. Kelley, had received a threatening letter containing dead ticks similar to ones sent to business executives this week.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 18 Jordan is firmly but unostentatiously giving Syria the staunchest public approval in the Arab world for the military intervention in Lebanon.

Henry S. Moyer Sr., retired president of the Moyer Company of Youngstown, Ohio, and national vice president of the American Council for Judaism, died yesterday in his home, 42 Cohawney Road in Scarsdale, N.Y. His age was 78.

FOR more than a decade, many people in eastern Suffolk County have been unhappy at being compelled to share county government with western Suffolk. Their reasons are obvious enough. Their problems are those of rapid growth and the consequent expansion in public services, schools and so forth that this growth compels, along with the mounting taxes.

O'Neill Jr., the House majority leader, acknowledged today that he had interceded with a Cabinet, officer to speed a decision on $2.2 million in annual rent Subsidies sought by a campaign contributor. Mr. Sinatra's previous wives were Nancy Barbato, Ava Gardner and Mia Farrow.

PARIS, June 22--With the accent more on controlling inflation than on reducing unemployment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development adopted today a 5 percent annual growth rate as a target for the industrial nations over the remainder of the decade.

CLORINDA, Argentina--In Buenos Aires, 600 miles to the south, shopkeepers nod listlessly behind counters or stand with arms folded at doorways waiting in vain for customers who can no longer afford more than basic necessities.

LISBON, June 22--The first new equipment that the Portuguese army has received from the United States in 10 years is beginning to arrive as part of an apparent effort to tighten Portugal's ties to the West through the North Atlantic alliance.

BOSWORTH PARK, England--A pub in this pastoral Leichestershire village is named for the Dixie family. Nearby is the nowdefunct Dixie Grammar School, which gave Samuel Johnson his first teaching job. The Dixies' ancestral home still stands, although now it is the local infirmary.

How does it come about that two men, each endowed with uncommon sensibilities, can be exposed for an extended period to the great dining salons of France and return to native soil, one to be immortalized as perhaps America's greatest gastronome, the other far better remembered for going out and flying a kite?

WASHINGTON, June 22-- The Democratic leadership of the House proposed 13 changes today in its administrative system in an effort to modernize bookkeeping and housekeeping accounts and prevent future scandals.

What had a teasing fancy, such as a wayward fairy tale, soon turned from gossamer into heavier stuff.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Those comparatively expensive little containers of "salt substitute" commonly sold in the supermarket diet section are generally useless unless a doctor has recommended the use of a salt substitute as part of a strict medical diet, according to a Federal Trade Commission consumer specialist.

BOSWORTH PARK, England--A pub in this pastoral Leicestershire village is named for the Dixie family. Nearby is the nowdefunct Dixie Grammar School, which gave Samuel Johnson his first teaching job. The Dixies' ancestral home still stands, although now it is the local infirmary.

The Schering-Plough Corporation announced yesterday that W.H. Conzen, its president, on Sept. 1 will assume the post of chairman, succeeding Abe Plough, who has been chairman since the company's formation in 1971 the consolidation of the Schering Corporation and Plough Inc.
Betty Ford led an audience of 2,500 people in an impromptu prayer last night after a prominent Jewish leader collapsed on the dais of the New York Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (Reuters)--Forty-eight Democratic members of the House of Representatives announced support today for Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. as their party's Vice-Presidential candidate.

PATERSON, June 22--"Is this the same neighborhood?" The question was asked by a Public School 12 teacher who had been away for a few days. What he missed was a mountain of rubbish on a lot across from the school. A street alongside the school also had a strange look: it was clean, swept spotless over the weekend after surviving years of constant litter.

HOUSTON, June 22 (UPI)-- Silas B. Ragsdale, 79 years old, former managing editor of The Galveston Daily News, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital following a heart attack.

BONN, June 22--Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Gen scher, speaking on behalf of the nine governments of the European community, called on South Africa today to live up to its responsibilities in reaching a peaceful solution of the Rhodesian problem.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 22--Eric Fromm gained the final of the New York State junior tennis championship today with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over John Galbraith at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. He plays Bob Rosello for the title tomorrow.

A special state investigator concluded yesterday that Governor Carey's decision last December to replace Maurice H. Nadjari had been "based upon his independent judgment," and not on his being influenced by "self-motivated" or "politically motivated people," as Mr. Nadjari charged at the time.
OTTAWA, June 22 (AP)-- The House of Commons gave preliminary approval today to a bill that would abolish capital punishment in Canada.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 23 (Reuters)--A Soviet literary journal today renewed its attack against three American correspondents stationed in Moscow who, it charged a month ago, were associated with the Central intelligence Agency.

BUFFALO, June 22 (AP)-- Dr. Thomas E. Headrick, vice president for academic affairs at Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis., has been chosen to be the new dean of the Law School at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

TRENNTON, June 22 (AP) --The State Department of Transportation announced today that more than 400 signs were being installed along New Jersey roads to help travelers identify historical sites in the state.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market retreated yesterday after Monday's advance. The Amex market value index closed at 104.70, down 0.35. The NASDAQ industrial index ended at 95.12, off 0.81.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 Running Tide, a famous 60-foot sloop from Annapolis, Md., was declared the winner of the Bermuda ocean race today. Increasingly the lessdeveloped countries see improved access to new technology as the key to their economic growth, and increasingly they are complaining that the technology re ceived from industrialized countries has been insufficient, too expensive or not really suitable to their particular needs.

ROME, June 23 Communist parties of Eastern and Western Europe are near final agreement on a declaration of common principles that would give all Communist parties the right to establish their own policies and even the implicit right to criticize the Russians and each other, authoritative sources said here today.

ALBANY, June 23 The Legislature's efforts to restructure the state court system slowed somewhat today when the Assembly put off action on proposed constitutional amendments to have Court of Appeals judges elected instead of appointed and to streamline the judiciary's disciplinary system.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn sentenced a high-school principal yesterday to confinement for refusing to obey a court order to carry out an ethnic survey required by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., June 23 A number of public officials today began pointing to New York City as the major source of raw sewage that has washed up on Long Island shores in recent weeks.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, NY., June 23 An oil barge ran aground in the St. Lawrence Seaway near here today, spilling 250,000 gallons of oil that threatened resort areas and wildlife. The spill, which halted seaway traffic for 15 hours, at 1:30 A.M., when the grounding caused three of her 16 storage tanks to rupture.
ALBANY, June 23 The most talked-about monument in modern state history has become the most gawked-about monument in modern state history.
Contemporary painting and sculpture does not lend itself to visions of imperial grandeur. It tends to look orphaned and forlorn in bombastic environments to...

WASHINGTON, June 23 Labor Department investigators have found that hundreds of millions of dollars in the teamsters' union's Central States Pension Fund is unaccounted for, and the department is considering putting Federal trustees in charge of the fund, sources close to the investigation said today.
